questions.text:
A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.

Na+: 145 mEq/L

K+: 4 mEq/L

Cl-: 90 mEq/L

HCO3-: 20 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 35 mEq/L. 

The anion gap is calculated as Na+ – [Cl- + HCO3-]. In this patient, the anion gap will be calculated as: 145 – (90 + 20) = 145 – 110 = 35 mEq/L.

Anion gap is representative of unmeasured anions which are normally present in the plasma, such as anionic proteins (albumin), phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions. When acid anions such as acetoacetate and lactate accumulate in the extracellular fluid, the anion gap increases, causing a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. A decrease in anion gap can occur due to an increase in abnormal cations (such as lithium, immunoglobulins), reduction in plasma albumin (nephrotic syndrome) or hyperviscosity and hyperlipidemia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady who recently went in for an IUCD contraception has increasing pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before her menses begin. The pain is relieved once the menses starts. What is the clinical diagnosis in this case?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
Pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before menses are suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

Fibromyalgia is a disorder with diffuse musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It is associated with irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, and depression. There is no cure for fibromyalgia as of now, although the symptoms can be controlled by medications. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious man showed pH- 6.9, HCO3- 13 mEq/L, paCO2- 68 mmHg. The acid-base status of this patient is best described as:

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

questions.solution:
According to the ABG analysis provided, the patient has a mixed acid-base disorder with simultaneous respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 6.9 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 13 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 68 mmHg indicating co-existing respiratory acidosis. The direction of pCO2 change is the same as that of pH change suggesting that this is a mixed acid-base disorder.

Step 4: The expected compensatory change in pCO2 in the metabolic acidosis calculated using Winter's formula would be:

pCO2 = [1.5xHCO3-] + 8 ± 2 = 26 - 30 mmHg

The actual pCO2 measure is very high (68 mmHg) compared to the estimated range of 26 - 30 mmHg indicating the presence of simultaneous metabolic and respiratory acidosis.

Note- If this was a case of uncompensated acidosis, either the bicarbonate or the pCO2 values would have been within the normal limits. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following features is not true for cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma?

choices.text: It is the second most common form of skin cancer

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is it has rolled out margins. An ulcer of SCC will have everted margins, not rolled-out margins.

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in situ include:

  • Bowen's disease- Full-thickness dysplasia in hypertrophic actinic (solar) keratoses
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat- Bowen's disease on the glans penis.

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including Imiquimod
  • Radiation therapy

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option C: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: An 8-month-old male infant is found to have bilateral renal masses. The infant had an omphalocele, macroglossia and macrosomia at birth. Which of the following is the genetic basis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with bilateral renal masses, and history of omphalocele, macroglossia, and macrosomia at birth most likely has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which occurs due to genomic imprinting.

Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome is characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia. omphalocele, visceromegaly and embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is the WT2 locus in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. This region contains multiple genes that are normally expressed from only one of the two parental alleles, with silencing (imprinting) of the other. IGF2 gene abnormalities have the strongest correlation to the development of tumors. Loss of maternal imprinting of IGF2 and uniparental paternal disomy of IGF2 are 2 pathways that can cause overexpression of IGF2 thus leading to tumorigenesis.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Other options: 

Option A: Mosaicism is the phenomenon where a single organism possesses more than one genetic line as the result of genetic mutation.

Option B: Anticipation is the phenomenon where symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.

Option D: De novo mutation such as germline deletions of 11p13 is associated with WAGR syndrome. In Denys-Drash syndrome the genetic abnormality is a dominant-negative missense mutation in the zinc-finger region of the WT1 protein that affects its DNA-binding properties.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of ulcerative colitis presents with abdominal pain, distention, and fever for the past 3 days. Her abdomen is distended, tympanic and tender to palpation. Plain abdominal X-ray is shown below. She has leukocytosis and elevated ESR and CRP. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of inflammatory bowel disease with abdominal pain and distension with fever coupled with colonic dilation on X-Ray makes toxic megacolon the likely diagnosis. The most appropriate management in this patient is the administration of high-dose intravenous corticosteroids.

The goal is to curb colonic inflammation, reducing the risk of perforation. Typically, these high-dose corticosteroids are given over 3-5 days. If there is an inadequate clinical or radiological response, colectomy becomes the subsequent step in management.

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), most commonly ulcerative colitis, characterized by rapid colonic dilation, ileus, and systemic toxicity. Prompt diagnosis and intervention are crucial due to the high risk of perforation and mortality.

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Other options:

Option B: Total abdominal colectomy with ileostomy, is a definitive surgical intervention but is usually reserved for patients with refractory toxic megacolon or those with contraindications to corticosteroids.

Option C: Advising the patient to be nil per oral with observation is insufficient management for toxic megacolon as it is a life-threatening condition.

Option  D: Oral mesalamine and antibiotics are not effective in treating toxic megacolon due to the severity of the inflammation and the need for systemic therapy. Antibiotics may be used empirically to cover potential bacterial translocation but are not the primary treatment.

questions.text:
An infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flaring, marked xiphoid retractions, and marked intercostal retractions. He also had an inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score in this case?

NICU: Neonatal intensive care unit
questions.solution:
Silverman-Anderson's score, in this case, would be 9.

  • Nasal flaring - marked - 2
  • Xiphoid retraction - marked - 2
  • Intercostal retraction - marked - 2
  • Chest movement - inspiratory lag - 1
  • Presence of audible expiratory grunt - 2

Total score: 9

The Silverman Anderson score is a commonly used score to assess respiratory distress. It provides an objective means of quantifying respiratory distress and also helps to assess the progression of distress over time and initiate treatment.

Silverman Anderson score:

Score

Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 Xiphoid retraction Nasal dilatation

 

Grunt
0 Sync none none none none
1 Lag on inspiration Just visible Just visible Minimal Stethoscope
2 See-saw Marked Marked Marked Naked ear

Silverman Anderson's retraction score is more suited for preterms with respiratory distress. However, Downes’ Score is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. 

Downe’s score:

Score  0  1  2
Respiratory rate <60/min  60–80/min >80/min
Air entry  Normal Mild decrease Marked decrease
Cyanosis  Nil In-room air On >40% oxygen
Grunting  None Only on auscultation Audible to naked ear
Retraction  Nil Mild Moderate

Downe’s score of >6 suggests impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. Selective fetal growth restriction, polyhydramnios and neural tube defects are seen as complications to several conditions and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, twins are separated solely by two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. Monochorionic monoamniotic gestation lacks a dividing membrane.

All monochorionic placentas likely have some anastomotic connections, unique to this type. Chronic feto-fetal transfusion may lead to the following clinical syndromes:

  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS)
  • Twin reversed-arterial-perfusion (TRAP) sequence

Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS):

TTTS is a fetal syndrome in monozygotic twinning with two amnionic sacs and a shared chorion, allowing for anatomical sharing of fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. This leads to transfusion from donor twin to recipient twin, resulting in donor anemia and restricted growth, while the recipient may suffer polycythemia, circulatory overload, and hydrops.

Features:

Donor twin  Recipient twin 
Oliguria Polyuria
Anemia Polycythemia
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Activation of Renin-angiotensin system (RAAS) Activation of Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
Decreased renal blood flow Increased renal blood flow
Non-visible bladder

Over distended bladder, circulatory overload, hyperviscosity syndrome, hyperbilirubinemia, hypertension 
Renal failure

Congestive cardiac failure (CCF), Hydrops twin (late cases )

The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I—Discordant amnionic fluid volumes+ urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II—Stage I + no visible urine in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV— frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—the demise of either fetus.

Treatment:

  • Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.
  • Septostomy is seldom done. 
  • Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid.
  • Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.
  • Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) by Solomon technique is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and a reduced likelihood of recurrence.

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome. So, the incidences of isolated oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios in twins are rare.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HIV comes with complaints of frothy urine and facial swelling. He has a past history of IV heroin use. His BP is 150/98 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a past history of heroin abuse and current HIV status, his current symptoms of frothy urine and edema of the face make focal segmental glomerulosclerosis(FSGS) the likely diagnosis.

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

These patients present with hypertension, edema, and nephrotic range proteinuria. 

Treatment: Prednisone, immunosuppressants to reduce the kidney injury. 

ACEis and ARBs to control the hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.solution:
The positive predictive value (PPV) of a screening test depends on the prevalence of the disease. The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has actually contracted the disease i.e., the likelihood that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease.

If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the more accurate will be the positive predictive value. Therefore, in a population with a high prevalence of the disease, a positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive. (Option A) Example: Hypothyroidism is more prevalent in hilly areas than in coastal areas. If someone from a hilly area tests positive he is more likely to have the disease than someone who tests positive in a coastal area.

Likewise, if the prevalence decreases, the PPV will also become low. So in a population with a low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test need not always mean true positive as it can produce an unacceptably high proportion of false positive results. 

Predictive value is affected the most by prevalence. However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

Options B & D: Sensitivity & specificity are independent of the prevalence of disease.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP

Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN

  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is diagnosed with dengue fever. He developed a saddleback fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of this fever pattern?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C

questions.solution:
In the saddleback type fever, which is seen in dengue, acute fever is followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days.

Pel-Ebstein fever is a fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. (Option C)

Continuous fever is characterized by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc. (Option A)

Remittent fever is characterized by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (Option D)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia infection and rat-bite fever)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected: Koilocytes with perinuclear halo and peripheral condensation of cytoplasm.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Cytohormonal study of vaginal epithelium

Pregnancy
