questions.text: A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is not associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
This neonate in the picture has congenital talipes equino varus (CTEV). Polyhydramnios is not associated with CTEV. 

In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or idiopathic clubfoot, the deformity is equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. Calf and medial foot tissues are underdeveloped. 

There are many mechanisms postulated for CTEV. Some of these include:

  • Mechanical compression of the foot in utero. This can be due to oligohydramnios, multiple gestations, etc
  • Ischemia of the calf muscles in utero
  • Genetic causes such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Neurological conditions such as meningocele (option C) and other spinal developmental disorders

Maternal obesity and maternal smoking (options A and D) are associated with CTEV.

Components of deformity:

  • Cavus - This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction - This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion - This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted, and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus - This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Equinovarus deformity causes inward twisting of the foot (shown below), with the sole facing posteromedially in severe cases. Associated disorders like congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida should be evaluated.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According  to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

  1. Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  2. Presence of bipedal oedema
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

questions.text: The below picture depicts ______
questions.solution:
The above picture depicts placenta with two lobes, hence the answer is placenta succenturiata.

Succenturiate Placenta

  • The second lobe is also known as the accessory lobe. 
  • Accessory lobe is attached to main lobe by membrane which has leash of blood vessels. 
  • A placenta containing three or more equally sized lobes is rare and termed multilobate.

Complication

  • Accessory lobe can be retained causing subinvolution, sepsis, Post-partum haemorrhage, vasa previa, fetal hemorrhage.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest x-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infrascapular region?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray and symptoms are suggestive of pleural effusion secondary to a lower respiratory tract infection. On examination, dullness to percussion will be observed.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to

  • excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity
  • decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics

Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

The etiology of pleural effusion can be of two types:

  • Exudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors. Examples include malignancy, infections, and pulmonary embolism.
  • Transudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors. Examples include congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option A: Hyperresonance is a sign of pneumothorax or emphysema.

Option B: Crackles are heard in cases of pulmonary edema or pneumonia.

Option D: Stridor is due to a lesion in the upper airways, usually tracheal or laryngeal.

questions.text: INSURE is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
INSURE is associated with respiratory distress in newborns. (Option A)

INSURE is abbreviated as intubate-intratracheal surfactant administration-extubation. It is a treatment modality performed in neonates with respiratory distress especially in preterm where surfactant production is reduced. It is indicated in neonates who are not maintaining oxygen saturation >90% while breathing 40-70% FiO2 in nasal CPAP(continuous positive airway pressure).

Extubation back to nasal CPAP is done immediately once the infant is stable, usually within minutes to <1 hr of surfactant administration. The amount of nasal CPAP required usually decreases after approximately 72 hr of age and most infants can be weaned from nasal CPAP. 

Variations of the INSURE method are MIST (minimally invasive surfactant therapy) and LISA (less invasive surfactant administration), in which a small feeding tube, rather than an endotracheal tube (ETT), is used to deliver intratracheal surfactant to a spontaneously breathing infant on nasal CPAP.

The combination of early rescue surfactant by these methods along with nasal CPAP has been associated with the reduced need for mechanical ventilation and prevention of bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is ligated first during surgical management of postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Anastomosis of uterine and ovarian arteries

questions.solution:
The uterine artery is the first artery that is ligated during the surgical management of postpartum hemorrhage(PPH).

If PPH is due to a flabby uterus on examination; then uterine massage is done to improve atony. Methergine 0.2 mg and oxytocin are administered to promote the contraction of the atonic uterus. Also, the uterus has to be explored for any retained membranes or cotyledons of the placenta.

Initial resuscitative measures include the infusion of 2L of normal saline (crystalloids) through large-bore IV cannulas. Relevant blood investigations such as blood count, grouping, cross-matching, LFT, RFT, and coagulation studies are done. 20 units of oxytocin in 1L of normal saline at the rate of 60 drops/minute is started along with blood transfusion. The bladder is catheterized.

Medical management of PPH includes carbetocin, a long-acting oxytocin analog, which is also effective. PGF-2 alpha, misoprostol(1000 micrograms), tranexamic acid, and calcium gluconate IV 1g slowly are given in refractory cases.


Uterine packing with balloon tamponade, foley catheter, and Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used as a first-line surgical intervention for atonic PPH.
Surgical methods for the management of atonic PPH in sequence are discussed below: 

  1. B -Lynch compression sutures act as a tamponade to control hemorrhage.
  2. The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated next.
  3. Uterine and ovarian arteries anastomosis are ligated if the bleeding persists.
  4. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and angiographic embolization is done if the above-mentioned methods failed.
  5. Following this, a hysterectomy is the last resort.

Related Pearl: Contraindications to Uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • A desire for future pregnancy: Poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions following UAE would negatively impact fertility, and result in obstetric complications or adverse fetal effects.
  • Postmenopausal status: The procedure is indicated primarily for premenopausal women since fibroids tend to decrease in size and symptoms improve or resolve after menopause. An enlarging uterus after menopause should raise the suspicion of malignancy and careful follow-up is warranted.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: They are pedunculated and may detach either intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. Detachment may be associated with sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: The volume of necrosis after UAE in a large fibroid uterus can be substantial with a proportionate level of postprocedural pain and risk of infection.
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the following type of epidemic shown in the image?

choices.text: It is often of infectious origin
It shows sharp rise and sharp fall

questions.solution:
The image given represents propagated epidemic. A propagated epidemic shows a gradual rise and a slower fall over a long time. It is most often infectious in origin and spreads from person to person. Herd immunity reduces transmission.

Types of epidemics include:

Single exposure /Point source epidemic Common source/continuous epidemic Propagated epidemic
Sharp rise and sharp fall in number of cases Sharp rise in number of cases Gradual rise and a slower fall over a long time
Clustering of cases in a narrow interval of time such that all cases develop within one incubation period of the disease Fall in number of cases is interrupted by "secondary waves/peaks" Results from "person to person transmission"

Eg: Food poisoning, Measles, Chicken pox, Cholera, Bhopal Gas tragedy

 Eg: Contaminated well in a village, Prostitute in a gonorrhea outbreak, Legionnaire's disease outbreak in Philadelphia Eg: HIV, TB 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which among the following structures is not derived from the Wolffian duct?
questions.solution:
Skene's tubercles are not derived from the Wolffian duct (mesonephric duct). It is a derivative of the urogenital sinus.

Derivatives of the Wolffian or Mesonephric duct:

  • Epoophoron (organ of Rosenmuller)
  • Paroophoron
  • Gartner’s duct

Derivatives of the Mullerian duct or Paramesonephric duct:

  • Fallopian tubes
  • Uterus
  • Upper three-fourths of vagina

Derivatives of the urogenital sinus:

  • Lower vagina
  • Skene’s tubercles
  • Bartholin’s gland
  • Urinary bladder 
  • Urethra

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males
Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra
Glans clitoris Genital tubercle Glans penis

Vestibular bulbs

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum

Corpus spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
Greater vestibular glands/Bartholin's glands Urogenital sinus Bulbourethral glands/Cowper's glands
Granulosa cells Sex cords Seminiferous tubules and Sertoli cells
Round ligament Gubernaculum Gubernaculum testis
Epoophoron and paroophoron Mesonephric tubules Efferent ductules and paradidymis
Gartner duct (remnant structure) Mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct Epididymis, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct
Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix and the upper vaginal wall Paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct Prostatic utricle and the appendix of testis (remnant structure)

questions.text: You are an intern observing a surgery where the stones from the bile duct are removed. The instrument given below is used. Name the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Desjardins choledocholithotomy forceps. It is used for the removal of stones from the common bile duct.

This is a long and slender instrument. The shaft is curved and there is a fenestra at the tip. It does not have a lock hence, accidental damage to CBD mucosa or crushing of the CBD stone is avoided.

Other options: 

Option A: Lane tissue-holding forceps have a stout and thick distal blade, with an oval fenestra in each blade. It has a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option B: Kocher forceps have an opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used for holding ribs during rib dissection and for holding the resected bowel.

Option D: Lister sinus forceps are used for draining pus from the abscess cavity in Hilton's method. Initially used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity. It has a long straight blade with serrations in the tip.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of falling off his bicycle. He complains of severe pain around his ankle. Which of the following findings is seen in this CT scan?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan of the ankle shows a Salter-Harris type II epiphyseal fracture, in which there is involvement of the growth plate (physis) and a triangular metaphyseal bone fragment, with sparing of the epiphysis. This triangular metaphyseal fragment is known as the Thurston Holland sign. 

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types. Type 2 epiphyseal fractures are the most common type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Other options:

Option A: Trethowan's sign is seen in slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). It is when Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis but passes superior to it.

Option B: Terry Thomas sign is seen in patients with scapholunate instability which denotes the increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate.

Option D: The teardrop sign is seen in orbital floor fractures and is also known as a blow-out fracture due to the herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary antrum.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: All of the following structures are removed in Patey’s operation except?

choices.text: Large portion of skin, the centre of which overlies the tumour but which always includes the nipple
All of the fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla

questions.solution:
Patey's modification of modified radical mastectomy and does not involve the removal of the axillary vein.  

Patey's modified radical mastectomy is a total mastectomy. It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes up to level III along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss). The incision used is an elliptical Stewart incision. 

Other eponymous modifications of mastectomy:

  • Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy is a modification of Patey's procedure in which pectoralis minor is incised and not removed following which the level III nodes are approached.
  • Halsted radical mastectomy involves excision of the breast tissue, skin, and nipple-areolar complex, dissection of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles. 
  • In Auchincloss modified radical mastectomy, pectoralis minor is left intact and level III nodes are not removed. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor divided
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: A young woman has an intense fear of cats. She also experiences palpitations, dizziness, and sweating when she comes in contact with the cats. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ailurophobia which refers to the fear of cats. It is a type of specific phobia.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. To diagnose this condition, the prerequisites are the development of intense anxiety or panic, when exposed to the feared object. 

The main defence mechanisms in phobias include displacement, projection, and avoidance. The DSM-5 includes distinctive types of specific phobia:

  • Animal type - e.g. cats, dogs
  • Natural environment type - e.g. storms
  • Blood-injection­ injury type - e.g. needles
  • Situational type - e.g. cars, elevators, planes
  • Other types - for specific phobias that do not fit into the previous four types

Treatment includes behavioural therapy like exposure-based and systematic desensitization. Pharmacotherapy with benzodiazepines, psychotherapy, or combined therapy directed to the attacks may also be beneficial. 

Other options: 

Option A: Xenophobia is a fear of strangers. 

Option B: Acrophobia is a fear of heights. 

Option D: Cynophobia is a fear of dogs.

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of fluid that can be detected by this x-ray view?
questions.solution:
The shown x-ray view is the lateral decubitus view, which can identify as little as 10–25 mL of pleural fluid.

Minimum amount of fluid required to be detected in pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view – 75 mL pleural fluid
  • PA view – 100 to 200 mL pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 mL pleural fluid

A chest x-ray of pleural effusion is shown below. Arrow A shows fluid layering in the right pleural cavity. Arrow B shows the normal width of the lung in the cavity

 

Radiological signs of pleural effusion:

  • Left lateral decubitus chest radiograph demonstrating the presence of free pleural fluid
  • The amount of pleural fluid can be semi quantified by measuring A.
  • The first finding that appears in frontal view is blunting of costophrenic angle.
  • Ellis-S curve – Lateral border of the pleural fluid level is higher than the medial border.
  • Best investigation for minimal pleural effusion is USG.

The image below depicts pleural effusion in chest x-ray PA view.

questions.text: A 60-year-old is brought to the psychiatrist with a 10-year history that he suspects his neighbors sneeze whenever he passes and they plan against him. He feels that his wife is replaced by a double, he called police for help, and he is alert, well groomed, and an occasional alcoholic. He is most probably suffering from:
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case scenario the patient is presenting with persecutory delusion – neighbors planning against him & delusion of misidentification – wife is replaced by a double i.e. Capgras syndrome , which are suggestive of paranoid schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia is a type of schizophrenia characterized by the presence of persecutory delusions, referential delusions, grandiose delusions and delusion of misidentification, often accompanied by hallucinations.

Option a: Paranoid personality is a Cluster A personality disorder with features like - quick to feel slighted and jealous, carry grudges, and distrustful and suspicious i.e. expect to be exploited and harmed by others. This doesn’t explain Capgras syndrome.

Option c: Patient is occasional alcoholic.

Option d: Conversion disorder doesn’t explain given symptoms.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: All of the following measures are correct regarding the management of frostbite except:

choices.text: Rewarming by asking the patient to exercise is not advised
Rapid rewarming can be accomplished by immersing the foot in a warm water bath
Rubbing/friction can be used to hasten up the process of rewarming
Tetanus prophylaxis must be given as there is increased risk of tetanus in frost bite

questions.solution:
Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. Affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

Image showing frost bite of the toes

questions.text: While on rounds in the post-operative ward,  you observe your senior teaching a patient who has undergone an open cholecystectomy two days ago, to use this device. What is the main purpose of using this device?
questions.solution:
The purpose of incentive spirometry in a post-operative patient is to prevent pulmonary atelectasis.

Atelectasis, especially of the lower lobes, is the most common respiratory complication in a post-operative patient and can be prevented by sitting the patient or inclining the bed, early mobilization, deep breathing exercises with incentive spirometry, and chest physiotherapy. Patients who are not fully awake may require non-invasive mechanical ventilation with PEEP. Correct manner of performing incentive spirometry is by taking sequential deep breaths so that all the balls or marker in the tube rise to the top, holding the breath for 5-6 seconds, and then exhaling. 

The primary pathophysiology of is inadequate expansion of the alveoli leading to their collapse. The factors predisposing to atelectasis are general anesthesia, upper abdominal and thoracic surgery. In the post-operative period, inadequate pain control may lead to poor inspiratory effort and and reduced diaphragm contraction in the patient's attempt to avoid experiencing pain,  may also contribute to the development of atelectasis. On the other hand, overuse of opioid analgesics or sedatives may also favour development of atelectasis due to respiratory depression causing collection of secretions. Other causes include lack of mobilization (bed-bound patients) or positional change.

Patients present with tachypnoea and decreased oxygen saturation and on examination, the breath sounds are bronchial in nature and reduced in intensity. Chest xray may show diminished lung volume, linear opacities, and elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side.

questions.text: Which of the following does not indicate chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI)?
questions.solution:
Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) includes ischemic rest pain, ulceration and gangrene, and ABPI <0.4. Chronic limb ischemia usually does not produce paralysis.

Chronic arterial occlusion in the legs presents as intermittent claudication. This is a cramp-like pain that is brought on by walking some distance and relieved by rest, usually within 5 minutes. The pain of intermittent claudication is absent on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis), but is brought on as the patient walks some distance. The distance that the patient is able to walk comfortably — known as claudication distance — decreases as the disease progresses.

At some point, the perfusion to the leg is so severely compromised that there's inadequate oxygen delivery even at rest. This stage is known as rest pain. This kind of pain is worse on lying down or elevation of the foot, because the perfusion is further compromised when the effects of gravity are absent. Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene. Patients with CLTI require urgent vascular intervention. Unlike acute limb ischemia, chronic limb ischemia usually does not result in paralysis and loss of sensation.

Quantitative assessment of peripheral arterial disease can be done with ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI). It is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is the numerator, and the highest brachial systolic pressure is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >1.4:  Calcified vessels (chronic kidney disease, diabetes)
  • >0.9 to < 1.4: Normal
  • <0.9: Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion
  • <0.4 – CLTI

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man developed severe pain abdomen and fever 3 days after undergoing surgery for bowel perforation. There is no dehiscence or discharge from the sutured wound seen. The intra-abdominal pressure was measured to be 25mm Hg. Which of the following physiological changes will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) 20 mm Hg or greater is suggestive of an abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). It is associated with an increased central venous pressure.

The normal IAP is 5-7 mmHg. When the IAP is > 12 mmHg, it is termed intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH). ACS develops when IAP is 20 mmHg or greater, with or without abdominal perfusion pressure less than 50 mm Hg it is associated with failure of one or more organ systems.

Diagnosis is made by measuring IAP using a urinary bladder (Foley catheter) or gastric catheter. CT scan, abdominal perfusion pressure and renal filtration gradient are some of the tests done to check organ dysfunction.

The primary goal of management is to reduce the IAP. So rapid decompression is done by opening the abdomen and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall using a mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag). After the resuscitation and management of the specific causes, a definite closure of the abdomen can be done by vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), split-skin graft, or prosthetic mesh.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text:
Which of the following vessels is indicated in the arrow?

NCCT - Non-contrast computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given NCCT image is suggestive of the Hyperdense MCA sign and the arrow points to the Middle Cerebral Artery.

Hyperdense MCA sign is seen due to the presence of thromboembolic material material within the lumen of the middle cerebral artery which appears hyperdense and may be suggestive of ischemic stroke as a dense vessel is the earliest detectable change on CT although it may disappear due to clot resolution, and such patients may be candidates for thrombolysis. Visualisation of a hyperdense vessel bilaterally is more likely to be suggestive of vessel calcification due to atheroscelrosis.

The following signs of acute ischemia can be seen on CT:

  • Blurring of the gray/white junction and effacement of the sulci due to ischemic swelling of the tissues.
  • Blurring of the margins of the gray matter structures
  • In cases of internal carotid artery occlusion or middle cerebral artery main segment (M1) occlusion, intraluminal clot may be seen as a focal hyperdensity, known as the hyperdense MCA sign or hyperdense dot sign.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-week-old neonate with lesions over the body and arms. On examination, thin-walled superficial vesicles are noted as shown in the image below. A disorder of the eccrine sweat gland is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows clear, thin‐walled, superficial vesicles 1–2 mm in diameter resembling drops of water, without any associated erythema. It is suggestive of miliaria, a disorder of eccrine sweat glands. 

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions, resulting in a leakage of sweat into the epidermis (miliaria crystallina and miliaria rubra) or dermis (miliaria profunda).

Other options: 

Option A: Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria is the obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.

Option B: Bromhidrosis is characterized by foul-smelling sweat usually due to infection of apocrine glands.

Option C: Milia, also known as “milk spots” are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts, located over the face usually. They resolve spontaneously without scarring and require no treatment.

Milia and miliaria may sound similar but are actually different from one another. Milia are epidermal inclusion cysts usually located on the face whereas miliaria is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland and is usually located on the body and arms. The clue given in the question is that the condition is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland. Hence, the answer is miliaria.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to emergency following a polytrauma. He is most likely to die if we don't prevent the triad of death.  Which of the following is not a component of the trauma triad of death?
questions.solution:
Alkalosis is not considered as a component of the triad of death in trauma patients. 

The trauma triad of death is a combination of clinical features that are seen in exsanguinating trauma patients and contribute to the majority of trauma-related mortality and morbidities. The triad includes:

  • Hypothermia
  • Coagulopathy
  • AcidosisIn a patient injured due to trauma, a state of shock develops which leads to hypoperfusion and then leads to lactic acidosis.

During the resuscitation phase of trauma, adequate precautions should be taken to prevent the development of these features.

  • Hypothermia is prevented by maintenance of ambient temperature within the patient’s room, usage of prewarmed IV fluids, blankets, etc.
  • Coagulopathy can be prevented by judicious use of i.v crystalloids (<1-1.5 Lit), early initiation of blood and blood products, usage of tranexamic acid, etc.
  • Acidosis can be prevented by correction of shock, ensuring adequate oxygenation, usage of sodium bicarbonate, etc.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the OPD with the following lesions shown in the image. It is present on the trunk and thighs but not on the palms and soles. Which of the following signs is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing reddish brown maculopapular lesions all over the body except palms and soles is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. Darier’s sign is positive in this condition.

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. It is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia in neonates.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in asymmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other options:

Option A: Headlight sign is the facial eczema sparing the periorbital, perinasal, and perioral areas. It is a feature of atopic dermatitis. Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous, pruritic patches or plaques, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy. Flexural surfaces are commonly involved in adults as seen in the image below.

Option B: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma and is caused due to the piloerection of the muscle.

Option C: Hertoghe's sign or Queen Anne's sign is defined as loss of lateral one-third of eyebrows (superciliary madarosis). It is seen in various conditions such as hypothyroidism, lepromatous leprosy, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, and alopecia areata.

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a succeptibility weighted imaging (SWI).

SWI is a form of MRI sequence that is especially sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic in nature.

The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences.

 Other options:

Gradient echo sequences(GRE): 

It uses gradient fields to generate transverse magnetization. In areas of hemorrhage, the iron that is present in the hemoglobin produces its own local magnetic field and dephases the spinning nuclei. This is useful to identify hemorrhagic contusions in the brain and pigmented villonodular synovitis.

Proton density image:

It is based on the number of nuclei in the area that is imaged. In PD-weighted image tissues with a higher density of protons produce stronger signals and appear brighter. PD-weighted image can be identified by comparing fluid with the fat signal. Fluids in these images appear greyish white similar or the appearance of fat in the body.

Inversion recovery sequences:

This MRI sequence is used to selectively null certain tissues. It can be:

  • Short tau inversion recovery(STIR) where fat is nulled. Fluids appear bright and fat appears dark in these images.
  • Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR) or double inversion recovery(DIR where fluid is nulled.- The fluid(CSF) normally appears dark and lesions appear to be brighter on these images.

FLAIR image:

questions.text: Which of the following flaps involves the isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and finally reconnection using microsurgery?
questions.solution:
Free flaps involve isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and then reconnection using microsurgery at the new site. 

Flaps are tissues that bring vascularity as they are transferred with their blood supply.

Types of flaps - 

  1. Random flaps -  Bears no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. It is basically three sides of a rectangle, the length to breadth ratio is less than 1.5:1. 'Delaying the flap' is a process in which cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation. It is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. A second procedure is conducted where it is raised further and finally transferred.
  2. Axial flaps - These are longer flaps. They are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  3. Pedicled/islanded flaps - They can be swung round on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ because of the axial blood supply. The business end of the skin being transferred can hence have the pedicle buried.
  4. Free flaps - In this case the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site 
  5. Composite flaps - Often skin with bone or muscle is transferred with the flap (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  6. Perforator flaps - Tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface. It is a subgroup of an axial flap.

questions.text: This sharp instrument depicted in the image below would be required in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a sharp uterine curette that is used only in molar pregnancy. The blunt curette is recommended to prevent a uterine perforation in a considerably soft uterus e.g. uterus in pregnancy or malignancy. In a non-pregnant uterus, uterine perforation is most likely to occur due to dilatation and curettage. 

The etiology of uterine perforation is as follows:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
  • Insertion of intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCD)- due to the lack of provider experience.
  • Spontaneous migration of IUCD within the myometrium
  • Hysteroscopy - diagnostic (e.g, hysteroscopic biopsy) or therapeutic (adhesiolysis) 
  • Laparoscopy

It can present with fever, acute abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding per vaginum. The management is as follows:

  • Conservative management - Fundal injuries are managed conservatively, as the myometrium contracts around the defect.
  • Surgical management:
    • Small defects can be repaired laparoscopically or hysteroscopically.
    • Emergency laparotomy - as abdominal viscera may prolapse through the defect. 
    • Hysterectomy - if the defect is large, and the patient has completed her family, hysterectomy is done as last resort.

questions.text: As an intern you are told to examine a patient diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. Which of the following best describes this condition?

choices.text: Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons
Abnormally dense bone due to defective osteoclast

questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Below is an image of a patient with Kienböck's disease in the left hand.

Other options:

Option B:  Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons is seen in De Quervain's disease.

Option C: Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Option D:  Abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation due to defective osteoclast function is seen in osteopetrosis. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of hip
  • Body of talus in fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of scaphoid in fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen in the fracture of neck of talus. Presence of this sign indicates that blood supply to the talus is adequate.

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor room. Which of the following parameters would you consider while calculating the APGAR score in a newborn?
  1. Respiratory rate 
  2. Pulse rate 
  3. Muscle tone
  4. Oxygen saturation
  5. Appearance
questions.solution:
The parameters to consider while calculating APGAR score in newborn babies are:

  1. Appearance
  2. Pulse rate (Heart rate)
  3. Grimace
  4. Activity(muscle tone)
  5. Respiratory effort.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for false positive APGAR score are:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: In your university practical exams, the external examiner displays the following retractors on the desk and asks you to pick the Deaver's retractor. What would you pick?
questions.solution:
If you were asked to pick Deaver's retractor you would pick the instrument labeled '1'.

The given image shows

1 - Deaver's retractor

2 - Doyen's retractor

3 - Morris retractor

4 - Czerny's retractor

Deaver’s retractor: It is used to retract the liver, spleen, and other abdominal viscera. It is atraumatic and gives adequate exposure of the surgical field.

Doyen's retractor: It is used in pelvic surgeries.

Morris retractor: It is used to retract the abdominal wall.

Czerny's retractor: It is used in surgeries like hernia, and laparotomy, especially during closure.

questions.text: The critical path in the flow chart given below includes how many days?
questions.solution:
Critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Here the red line signifies the critical path and it includes 9 days.

Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: In an Rh-negative pregnancy, which of the following parameters of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) doppler is used to detect fetal anaemia?

choices.text: An increase in peak systolic velocity
A decrease in mean systolic velocity

questions.solution:
Increased peak systolic velocity in fetal MCA doppler is used to detect fetal anemia in RH negative pregnancy.

In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity also increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.

If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the x-ray showing Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae point towards the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain. Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis. Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • Periarticular sclerosis in later stages 
  • Squaring of vertebrae due to the flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • Wedging of the vertebra, leading to hyperkyphosis

Complications of ankylosing spondylitis include

  • Spinal fractures, the most common site is C5–7 
  • Hyperkyphosis
  • Spinal cord compression
  • Lumbosacral nerve root compression

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

The image below shows the bamboo spine's appearance:

Other options :

Option b : Paget's disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance.

Option c : TB spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Option d : Osteopetrosis is characterized by abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation. The skull base is uniformly radio-dense and radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the rugger-jersey appearance.

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a swelling as shown in the image which can be moved horizontally but not vertically. Also, fingers were raised but not separated when placed on the surface of the tumor. Based on the above clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a tumour on the lateral side of her neck which does not permit vertical movement but only horizontal movement as well as transmitted pulsation is most likely a carotid body tumour.

The pulsatile swellings, which originate from the arteries, include aneurysms and vascular growths like carotid body tumours. The pulsations of the swellings, which are located in close proximity to the artery and lie superficially to it, can be observed. The phenomenon referred to as transmitted pulsation is distinguished from expansile pulsation, which is generated by the artery walls. Expansile swellings would not only lift the finger but also separate the fingers whereas transmitted pulsations only lift the fingers but do not separate them.

Carotid body tumour:

  • It arises from the chemoreceptor cells in the carotid body, hence called chemodectoma.
  • Mostly presents after 40 years.
  • It is a very slow-growing tumour.

Features:

  • Painless swelling which is pulsatile.
  • Bruit can be heard with a stethoscope.
  • It moves from side to side but not vertically.
  • It may extend into the parapharyngeal space and present in the oropharynx.
  • Some tumours are functional and secrete catecholamines.

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI with gadolinium are diagnostic and also show the extent of the tumour. MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign). Serum catecholamines and urinary meta-nephrines and vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) should be estimated.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or biopsy should not be done because of the vascularity of tumour.

MRI angiography below shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries - Lyre’s sign


Other options:

Option A: Neurofibroma is a benign tumour arising from the connective tissue of the nerve containing ectodermal, neural and mesodermal connective tissue components. It can be single or multiple. It is the most common intradural extramedullary spinal tumour. Neurofibromas can be local, generalized (von Recklinghausen's disease) or plexiform types. Patients present with mild pain or a painless swelling usually in the subcutaneous or cutaneous plane with tingling, numbness and paraesthesia along the distribution of the nerve.  They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations. 

Option B: A lipoma is a soft painless swelling. It shows the characteristic slip sign and is freely mobile. They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations. 

Option C: Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. Identify the subtype of breast cancer based on these findings.
questions.solution:
The above image shows immunohistochemistry staining positive for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors, which is triple positive or luminal type B of breast cancer.

Immunohistochemistry staining:

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors; hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor; hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors(50% to 65% of tumors) –Range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas(“triple-negative” or “basal-like”) are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter that the obstetrician is measuring in the image below is _______.
questions.solution:
The AP diameter that the obstetrician is measuring is the diagonal conjugate.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾").
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4").
  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm.

The clinically diagonal conjugate is measured, and the obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of scanty episodes of bleeding but is regularly timed. This menstrual cycle irregularity is called _____.
questions.solution:
Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding.

Menstrual cycle irregularities definitions:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
  • Metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding.
  • Oligomenorrhea denotes infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. 
  • Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>7 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation denotes the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding denotes vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her 27th week of gestation is suspected to have gestational diabetes mellitus. Which of the following tests can be done to arrive at the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The glucose tolerance test is considered as the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

Diagnostic criteria with 75 g are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hr: 153 mg/dl

Note: Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result for this test were then subject to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. This has now been replaced by the one-step approach that omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text:
A patient complains of difficulty in maintaining balance while walking at night for the past 2 months. On examination, he has spastic weakness in both lower limbs, a positive Babinski sign, and an absent ankle jerk. Laboratory results are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL

MCV: within normal limits
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sensory ataxia (patient is unable to maintain balance without visual input), UMN signs (spasticity and positive Babinski sign), and absence of ankle jerk due to peripheral neuropathy point to a diagnosis of subacute combined degeneration of cord (SACD). Note that neurological symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency can occur without anemia and macrocytosis.

SACD is a degeneration of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord, which occurs as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients present with sensory ataxia (involvement of the dorsal column) and UMN type of motor symptoms such as spasticity and positive Babinski sign (involvement of corticospinal tract). Because of coexisting peripheral neuropathy, deep tendon reflexes can be absent. Some patients also develop cortical defects such as dementia.

The treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency when the patient has neurological symptoms is with cyanocobalamine 1000 mcg given intramuscularly, first daily for 1 week → then weekly for 1 month → then monthly for the rest of the patient's life.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with syringomyelia present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back, and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option A: Although UMN type of motor symptoms are seen in ischemic stroke as well, they are unilateral. Furthermore, stroke is an acute onset clinical syndrome, while this patient has had these complaints for the past 2 months.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of fatigue and easy bruising. Peripheral smear demonstrates pancytopenia with macrocytosis and hyposegmented neutrophils. Bone marrow aspirate is hypercellular showing dyserythropoiesis with ringed sideroblasts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fatigue, easy bruising, peripheral smear showing pancytopenia with macrocytosis and hyposegmented neutrophils, and bone marrow examination showing dyserythropoiesis with ringed sideroblasts is suggestive of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). 

MDS is a hematogenous disorder characterized by bone marrow failure and cytopenias. It is a disorder seen in the elderly. Patients present with features of marrow failure such as fatigue, dyspnea, pallor, easy bruising, and increased risk for infections. 

Evaluation involves a complete blood count, peripheral smear, and bone marrow examination. The peripheral smear reveals bi- or pancytopenia with macrocytosis. Platelets are large and neutrophils are hypogranulated and hyposegmented. Bone marrow examination shows a hypercellular marrow with dyserythropoietic changes and ringed sideroblasts. There is an increase in myeloblasts. The proportion of blasts determines the disease prognosis. 

MDS has a high risk for AML transformation. Progression to leukemia is associated with a poor prognosis. Management involves the use of drugs like lenalidomide which is particularly useful in patients with chromosomal 5q deletion. Other agents used in management include erythropoietin analogs and hypomethylating agents (eg. azacitidine, decitabine). 

Related Pearl: Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series appears as

  • Ring sideroblasts- Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm
  • Megaloblastoid maturation- Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities- Nucleus with abnormal shape

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series 

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes- 

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to conclusively localize a parathyroid adenoma?
questions.solution:
The best method to conclusively localise a parathyroid adenoma is SPECT sestamibi. Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues. It can also detect ectopic glands in the mediastinum or in the deeper cervical region.

Ultrasonography:

  • It is inexpensive and noninvasive.
  • Mediastinal parathyroid tissue cannot be detected because USG cannot penetrate the sternum or clavicle.

Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi (Tc99 sestamibi scan) is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. Tc99 sestamibi scan is a 2D study, so SPECT sestamibi, which is a 3D study is preferred over Tc99 sestamibi.  scan. SPECT sestamibi has high specificity and sensitivity as compared to Tc99 sestamibi.

MRI is rarely used because of its low sensitivity. Occasionally, MRI may be indicated in pregnant patients in whom ultrasound is noninformative because MRI avoids radiation exposure.

questions.text: The USG of the gall bladder of a forty-year-old obese female patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography of the gallbladder shows acoustic shadow, indicating the presence of stone in the gallbladder (cholelithiasis).

Cholelithiasis is commonly seen in women. Over 70% of the gallstones are composed of cholesterol, while the pigment gallstones composed of calcium carbonate constitute most of the remaining 30%.

Radiological features:

X-ray: Only calcified stones are visible.

Ultrasonography:

  • The gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast acoustic shadow. Stone mobility may be demonstrated, if it is not impacted.
  • In contrast, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow.
  • In gallbladder full of stones, there is a dense acoustic shadowing with the presence of two parallel curved echogenic lines separated by a thin anechoic space. This characteristic appearance is referred to as ‘Double-arc shadow sign’, or wall-echo-shadow sign.

The image-below shows wall-echo-shadow sign due to the presence of a large gall stone.

Other options:

Option A: Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall. The image below shows calcification in the gall bladder wall(on CT) suggestive of a porcelain gall bladder.

Option B: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. The image below shows a gallbladder polyp on USG:

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.

The iodization of salt is used as a prophylactic measure against endemic goiter. In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for circumcision under daycare surgery. Which of the following is not a requirement for a successful daycare surgery?

choices.text: Patient's age is more important than physiological status

questions.solution:
The physiological status of a patient is a more important determinant than their chronological age during daycare surgery. Thus, the opposite, as mentioned in option (B) is not an essential requirement for a successful daycare surgery. 

A surgical procedure can be considered as daycare surgery when the patient's admission, procedure, and discharge all take place within the span of 12 working hours. In these procedures, the patient does not have to stay overnight at the hospital. 

Minimal tissue handling during the procedure (Option D), achieving good hemostasis (Option B), and using minimally invasive techniques (Option A) are all factors that can help to achieve a successful daycare surgery. 

Physical fitness for the procedure, short duration, and a home environment that can support recovery and postoperative care are all important factors when choosing daycare surgery for a patient.

When selecting a patient it is important to consider the following-

  • Medically, the physiological health of the patient is of greater importance than their chronological age. For short procedures, the current health status will help us decide if the patient will tolerate the procedure or not. Chronological age becomes more important for longer, more invasive surgeries. 
  • Surgically, the procedure should ideally last less than 2 hours, and the patient should be able to consume liquids and possibly some solid food by the time they get discharged on the same day. 
  • Socially, it is important to identify a designated caregiver for the patient at least for the first 24 hours after surgery. Their home should also have the facilities to support their recovery and they should be sent home with all the sites required for their post-operative care. 

Some procedures that qualify for daycare surgery are listed below-

  • Arthroscopies
  • Biopsy (temporal, lymph node)
  • Reducing a strangulated hernia
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess 
  • K-wiring of a finger or wrist bone fracture
  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy

Patient's having daycare surgery can usually be discharged when they have stable vitals, have adequately controlled pain with a prescription for further pain management at home, can perform basic activities on their own, have no evidence of incision site bleeding, have a designated caregiver, and have all the instructions required for further management at home and instructions in case of an emergency.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman who desires future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
