questions.text: What is the condition seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the pelvic region, which is known as ischiopagus.

In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Depending on the degree of incomplete separation, different types of conjoined twins can form:

  • Craniopagus: United at the head
  • Thoracopagus: United at the thorax 
  • Cephalothoracopagus: Fusion of both head and thorax
  • Omphalopagous or Xiphipagous: United anteriorly from the xiphoid to the umbilicus
  • Parapagus: Lateral fusion with two heads, sharing a single thorax, abdomen, and pelvis (most common)
  • Ischiopagus: United at the pelvis 
  • Pygopagus: United in the sacral region
  • Heteropagous: Asymmetric forms

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the emergency room with polytrauma. Which of the following is not considered as an adjunct to the primary survey?

AP- Anteroposterior

PA- Posteroanterior
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray PA view is not a part of a primary survey. Chest X-ray is done in AP view in primary survey of trauma care.

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat life-threatening conditions.
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate). If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion). Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation). This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale along with pupil reactivity score (GCS-P).
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey: These help in the evaluation of other life-threatening processes.

Monitoring- 

  • Electrocardiograph (ECG) is done to evaluate cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade.
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring to detect any changes in heart rate and rhythm.
  • Continuous oxygen monitoring via pulse oximetry.
  • Ventilation monitoring via capnography and arterial blood gas analysis.

Catheters-

  • Urinary catheters help in the evaluation of fluid status.
  • Gastric catheters decompress the stomach and reduces the risk of aspiration.

Imaging-

  • Trauma triple radiographs of the cervical spine, chest, and pelvis, even in pregnant women. 
    • Cervical spine lateral view to look for spinal injury.
    • Chest AP view is done to evaluate for pneumothorax, hemothorax, rib fractures, or aortic injury.
    • Pelvis AP view to evaluate for pelvic fractures.
  • Ultrasound FAST Examination is the "Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma". It is performed to detect pericardial and intraperitoneal blood. The Extended FAST (E-FAST) includes examination of the thoracic cavity.
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is done to detect intraperitoneal bleed.
  • Emergency computed tomography (CT)

These specialised forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerised tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey, and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

Laboratory studies-

  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess oxygentaion, ventilation, and pH.
  • Blood typing and grouping for blood transfusion.
  • Complete blood count and coagulation studies in anemic patients or patients using anticoagulation drugs.
  • Pregnancy test in any woman of child-bearing age.
  • Urinalysis in pelvic or abdominal trauma.
  • Urea and electrolytes, blood glucose levels, and toxicology studies in patients with unexplained altered mental status.

questions.text: Perception of pain in an area that lacks sensation is known as?
questions.solution:
Perception of pain in an area that lacks sensation is known as anesthesia dolorosa.

 This condition is particularly paradoxical because it involves pain perceived in an area that has lost normal sensation, often as a result of nerve injury or a neurological condition. It's most commonly associated with conditions affecting the trigeminal nerve or following neurosurgical procedures.

Other options:

Option B: Unpleasant or abnormal sensation with or without a stimulus is called dysesthesia.

Option C: Abnormal sensation perceived without an apparent stimulus is called paresthesia.

Option D: Increased response to mild stimulation is called hyperesthesia.

Related Pearl: Definitions in pain management

  • Allodynia- perception of ordinary non-noxious stimulus as pain
  • Analgesia- absence of pain perception
  • Anesthesia- absence of all sensation
  • Anesthesia Dolorosa- pain in area that lacks sensation
  • Dysesthesia-Unpleasant or abnormal sensation with or without a stimulus
  • Hypalgesia- diminished response to noxious stimulus
  • Hyperalgesia- increased response to noxious stimulation
  • Hyperesthesia- increased response to mild stimulation
  • Hyperpathia- presence of hyperesthesia, allodynia, hyperalgesia usually associated with over reaction, and persistence of the sensation after the stimulus
  • Hypoesthesia- reduced cutaneous sensation (e.g. light touch, pressure, temperature)
  • Neuralgia- pain in the distribution of nerve or a group of nerve
  • Paresthesia- Abnormal sensation perceived without an apparent stimulus
  • Radiculopathy- functional abnormality of one or more nerve root.

questions.text: A college student presents with fever, headache, and confusion. Lumbar puncture was positive for HSV DNA, detected by PCR. An MRI brain is done to localize the lesions. Which area on the brain is most likely to show lesions?
questions.solution:
The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis has been the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe.

Investigation of choice includes HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR. 

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes.

questions.text: An obese man was posted for bariatric surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice for this patient.

In obese individuals, the increased fat stores increase the volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs when compared to a lean individual of the same body weight. This increases the peripheral distribution of the lipid-soluble agents thus resulting in increased recovery time. There is an increase in the cardiac output in obese individuals that increases the early distribution of the drugs. Hence fat-soluble drugs should be administered based on the total body weight. Water-soluble agents like neuromuscular blockers have a smaller peripheral distribution that is minimally increased by body fat. Therefore, water-soluble agents are dosed based on the ideal body weight.

Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity. 

Inhalational agent Blood-gas partition coefficient
Halothane 2.5
Isoflurane 1.4
Sevoflurane 0.65
Desflurane 0.45

Blood-gas partition co-efficient determines the solubility of the anesthetic agent in the blood. The higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the higher will be the solubility of the anesthetic agent. This leads to its greater uptake by pulmonary circulation. The higher the uptake of the anesthetic agent, the higher the difference between the inspired and alveolar concentrations, which leads to a slower rate of induction and recovery. Desflurane has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). Thus, the alveolar and blood concentrations rapidly rise to the level of inspired concentration, providing rapid induction of anesthesia and rapid recovery.

Other options:

Option A- Halothane is a high fat-soluble agent and can result in halothane hepatitis due to increased metabolism in obese individuals. Hence it is avoided.

Option C- Sevoflurane has a relatively higher fat solubility compared to desflurane.

Option D- Isoflurane has a higher fat-gas partition co-efficient resulting in increased recovery time from anesthesia.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a loss of appetite and increasing fatigue for the last few weeks. The following abnormality is noted on examination. Identify the cause of the nail changes.
questions.solution:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states such as renal failure.

Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discolouration of the nail. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiformae, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed - leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

  • Lung cancer

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with painless swelling on the side of his neck anterior to the muscle. On examination, swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. How would you manage the patient?

choices.text: Advise a CECT scan of the neck

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a Branchial cyst. In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Branchial cysts arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Clinical Features:

  • Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate.
  • Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescence and early 3rd decade.
  • Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue.
  • It may get infected to form an abscess.
  • FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment:

  • Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent.
  • Although the anterior aspect of the cyst is easy to dissect, it may pass backward and upwards through the bifurcation of the common carotid artery as far as the pharyngeal constrictors.
  • It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.
  • In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Other options:

Option A: Excision would be the treatment of choice in a patient who is less than 35 years old
 
Option C: Reviewing after 6 months is not correct for a patient who is more than 35 years old as there is a high degree of suspicion of malignancy.
 
Option D: CT scan of the neck is not a recommended initial screening tool for a branchial cyst.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD now complains of swelling in both feet for 6 months, dyspnoea on exertion and dry cough for 1 week. An ECG was done and the lead II showed this pattern. Which of the following options is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called "P pulmonale".  The patient is showing features of right heart failure and right atrial overload is responsible for the above ECG finding.

The features of P pulmonale include:

  • Amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II.
  • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1.

questions.text: A 10-year old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections, and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10gm/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a young child with recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea with stool fat more than 10 gm/day is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). A distal intestinal obstruction is a common complication seen in this age group.

Protein-losing enteropathy occurs due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and is seen most commonly in infancy (Option A). Rectal prolapse was one of the common complications in the past but occurs less frequently due to earlier diagnosis and initiation of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (Option D). Individuals with CF develop hypovolemic hyponatremia by sodium loss via sweat through a defective chloride ion transport channel, the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), and hence hypernatremia is not seen in cystic fibrosis (Option C).

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues caused primarily due to a mutation in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator [CFTR] gene which serves as an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells and regulates the volume and composition of exocrine secretion. A defect in this gene results in thick, hyper-viscous exocrine secretions which lead to the primary pathologies seen in cystic fibrosis.

Disease manifestations include:

  • Respiratory: Copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. Bacterial flora (including Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) is routinely cultured from CF sputum.
  • Pancreas: Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes. There is tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue.
  • Hepatic: Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and multilobular cirrhosis.
  • GIT: Contents of the intestinal lumen are often difficult to excrete, leading to meconium ileus in the newborns and distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults. With early diagnostic modalities and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, the occurrence of rectal prolapse is fairly rare.
  • Infertility:
    • Males- developmental abnormality secondary to improper secretion by the vas or associated structures leading to complete involution of the vas deferens and infertility. About 99% of males with CF are infertile
    • Females-  abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions leads to an increased incidence of infertility
  • Sinusitis: Present in most CF patients

questions.text: A non alcoholic factory worker in a groundnut factory developed hepatocellular carcinoma. What is the most probable cause in this worker who has been working there for a long time?
questions.solution:
Aflatoxin is the most probable cause in this patient as he is working in a groundnut factory.

Aflatoxins:

  • These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus (secretes B1) and A. parasiticus (secretes B1, B2, G1 and G2)
  • Frequently present in moldy foods, like groundnuts, corn, and peas.
  • These toxins are highly toxic to animals and birds, as well as to human beings.
  • Known to cause hepatomas in lower animals, and carcinogenic effects in humans have also been seen.

Risk factors for HCC

  • HBV, HCV, aflatoxin, alcohol
  • Hereditary hemochromatosis, α1AT deficiency, Wilson disease, metabolic syndrome, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Other options:

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism.

Sanguinarine is the toxic compound causing epidemic dropsy.

questions.text: Branches from which of the following vessels form the vascular pedicle for a latissimus dorsi flap?
questions.solution:
The vascular pedicle for the latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is based on the thoracodorsal artery, which is a branch of the subscapular artery.

A surgical flap is used to transfer tissue with its blood supply, from a donor area, to reconstruct a defect in the recipient artery. A flap is composed of a base, pedicle and tip, and the pedicle contains the blood supply. Flaps are broadly classified as follows:

Classification of muscle flaps
Based on blood supply

Random flap 

Unnamed vessel supplying flap

Axial flap

Named vessel supplying flap. 
Method of movement

Local transfer 

  • Rotation flap
  • Transposition flap
  • Advancement flap

Distant transfer 

  • Pedicle flap
  • Free flap
Based on composition

Simple Flap

  • Cutaneous flap
  • Musculocutaneous 
  • Fasciocutaneous

 

Composite flap

  • Osseocutaneous flap
  • Sensory flap

 

Other options:

Option B: A pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (PMMF) is based on the pectoral branches of the thoraco-acromial artery.

Option C: A serratus anterior flap is based on the lateral thoracic artery.

Option D: A deltopectoral flap (Bakamjian flap) is based on the perforating branches of the internal mammary artery.

questions.text: A 55 year-old man with cirrhosis presents with progressive dyspnea that worsens significantly when he sits and improves when he lies down. Pulse oximetry reveals hypoxemia in the upright position. What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS), characterized by platypnea (dyspnea worsening on standing and relief on lying supine) in patients with portal hypertension due to cirrhosis.

Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS) is a rare complication of cirrhosis characterized by hypoxia without significant lung disease. The development of abnormal vascular connections within the lungs (intrapulmonary vascular shunts), bypasses gas exchange in the alveoli, and is a characteristic of hepatopulmonary syndrome. Additionally, metabolites (rich in H+ ions) produced in a cirrhotic patient leads to additional vasodilation of the lung vessels.

Since the shunts typically arise in the lung bases, an upright posture causes the patient's shunt fraction to rise.  This leads to orthodeoxia (hypoxia in the upright position) and platypnea (the sensation of shortness of breath when upright). This is due to the majority of the blood supply being diverted to the lower lobes and thus bypassing the oxygen rich upper lobes.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary edema is not likely to present with platypnea and orthodoxia. While fluid accumulation can occur in the lungs with advanced cirrhosis, it is also important to note that the primary mechanism of HPS-related dyspnea is shunting, not edema. 

Option C: Portopulmonary hypertension presents with hypoxia and symptoms of right heart failure. Platypnea and orthodoxia are not classical.

Option D: Ascites can cause pleural effusions, but these typically cause dyspnea regardless of posture, not the characteristic platypnea seen in HPS.

questions.text: During a knife fight, a 22-year-old male sustained a stab injury to the abdomen. Which is the most common organ injured in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
The liver is the most common organ damaged in a penetrating stab injury of the abdomen.

  • Most common organ injured in blunt trauma of abdomen: Spleen > Liver
  • Most common organ injured in penetrating abdominal stab injury: Liver
  • Most common organ injured in penetrating gun shot injury: Small intestine.
  • In penetrating abdominal trauma due to stab wounds, the most commonly injured organs are as follows : liver > small bowel > diaphragm > colon.
  • In penetrating abdominal trauma due to gunshot wounds, the most commonly injured organs are as follows  : small bowel > colon > liver >abdominal vascular structures.

questions.text: A child presents with fever for the past 5 days along with rash and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. On examination, the following finding was noted in the soft palate of the child. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever with rash, suboccipital lymphadenopathy, and the image showing Forchheimer's spots (tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate) point to the diagnosis of rubella. 

Rubella, also known as German measles is caused by the rubella virus, an enveloped RNA virus belonging to the family Togaviridae. 

The period of infectivity is usually a week before and a week after the onset of the rash appears and the incubation period is around 2-3 weeks. The child presents with low-grade fever, centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy (suboccipital, postauricular, and anterior cervical lymph nodes). Forchheimer spots may be present.

Other options:

Option B: The measles virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Treatment is supportive. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media.

Option C: Varicella presents with fever, malaise, and anorexia, followed by a pruritic maculopapular rash, which forms vesicles with a characteristic cropping distribution (simultaneous presence of lesions in various stages of evolution).

Option D: Mumps is caused by a virus belonging to Paramyxoviridae and the genus Rubulavirus. It is an acute self-limited infection characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid swelling and tenderness, and the frequent occurrence of meningoencephalitis and orchitis.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling, and early morning stiffness in multiple joints for the past 6 months. Blood tests reveal positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. X-rays show early erosions in the small joints of the hands.  Which of the following drugs is not used in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of pain, swelling and early morning stiffness in multiple joints with a positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies likely has Rheumatoid arthritis. Febuxostat is not used in rheumatoid arthritis. It is used in the treatment of gout.

Meanwhile, the rest of the drugs can be used to treat Rheumatoid arthritis.

M/C extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules

M/C cardiac involvement Pericarditis
M/C valvular lesion Mitral regurgitation
M/C hematologic abnormality Normochromic, normocytic anemia
M/C part of the spine involved Cervical spine
M/C type of lymphoma Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
M/C cause of death Cardiovascular disease

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl who was diagnosed with SLE at 13 years of age is now refractory to standard treatment. She is prescribed a monoclonal antibody which is an anti-B-cell activator. Which of the following drugs is she prescribed?
questions.solution:
Belimumab is a monoclonal antibody that is an anti-B-cell activator. It is used in the management of lupus refractory to standard treatment. 

Belimumab inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and autoantibodies. It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show a response to initial therapy with steroids.

Other options:

Option A: Rozanolixizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that has been recently FDA-approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.

Option C: Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist that binds to CD25 and is used in the relapsing type of multiple sclerosis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha agent used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) are correct?
1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
5. No vaccination is needed in case of an emergency splenectomy
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 3 and 4 are correct regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). The risk of developing OPSI is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. 

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli.

The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: If identified and intervened early, rapid clinical improvement can be expected in a patient with which of the following causes of dementia ?
questions.solution:
If diagnosed and intervened early, clinical improvement can be expected with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), as it is a reversible cause of dementia.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus can present with the following triad (Adam’s triad or Hakim's triad), remembered as:

  1. Urinary incontinence (wet)
  2. Dementia (wacky)
  3. Gait disturbance (wobbly)           

Causes of dementia:

Reversible Irreversible
  • Intracranial tumors
  • Subdural hematoma
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Meningitis 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lewy body disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
  • Pick's disease

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

CONDITION FEATURES
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of torsion of the testis in adolescents?

choices.text: Seperation of the epididymis from the body of the testis
Abnormal contraction of the cremastric muscles

questions.solution:
The most common cause of torsion of the testis is the high investment of tunica vaginalis which causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell (bell­clapper abnormality). This is typically a bilateral abnormality.

For torsion to occur one of the following abnormalities must be present:

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

Testicular torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable. Contralateral orchiopexy is performed to prevent recurrence in the unaffected testis.

Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.

The below image shows a gross specimen of torsion testis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula.

Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Lymphogranuloma venerum
  • Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula
  • Diverticulitis 
  • Carcinoma cervix
  • Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the outpatient department with complaints of reddish vaginal discharge after 3 days of delivery. Her vitals were stable and there were no associated signs of sepsis. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lochia rubra.

Lochia is a type of vaginal discharge seen in the first fortnight during puerperium. Depending on the color it is named as:

  • Lochia rubra is red in color and seen during the first 1-4 days.
  • Lochia serosa is yellowish or pale brownish and seen during the initial 5-9 days.
  • Lochia alba is pale white in appearance and is seen 10-15 days postpartum.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: All of the following are protective factors for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) except _________
questions.solution:
IUCD users are a risk factor for PID and not a protective factor.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

Note: Several studies in developed and developing countries have found that current or recent OC use reduces the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, a major cause of female infertility. These studies have found that OC use lowers the risk by, on average, about 40 percent. Two mechanisms may be operative:

  • OCs may change the cervical mucus such that it prevents pathogenic organisms from ascending into the upper genital tract; or
  • OCs reduce menstrual blood flow, thus decreasing the amount of medium available for bacterial growth.

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not removed in a modified radical hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
In modified radical hysterectomy/Type II hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are not removed. They are ligated at the level of the ureter. 

Structures removed in Type II hysterectomy:

  • Uterus
  • Cervix
  • Proximal 1-2cm (upper 1/3rd) of the vagina
  • Parametrial and paracervical tissue medial to the ureter
  • Pelvic nodes

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple hysterectomy/ extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical hysterectomy/ Wertheim hysterectomy
  • Type III - Radical hysterectomy/ Meigs-Wertheim hysterectomy
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration

    Main differences between a modified radical hysterectomy (type II) and a radical hysterectomy (type III):

      Modified radical hysterectomy Radical hysterectomy
    Uterine artery Ligated at the level that it crosses the ureters Ligated at the origin from the internal iliac artery
    Cardinal ligaments Medial half of cardinal ligaments resected Cardinal ligaments divided at the sidewall
    Uterosacral ligament  Divided midway between uterus and sacrum Divided at sacrum
     Vagina 1-2cm of the proximal vagina (upper 1/3rd of the vagina) removed >2cm of the upper vagina (upper 2/3rd of the vagina) removed

questions.text: Hysteroscopy is not advised in which of the following patients?

questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy is contraindicated in a patient with acute genital tract infection.

Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides the endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic.

  • Endometrial tuberculosis
  • Misplaced IUCD
  • Endometrial lesions

  • Asherman syndrome

Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows:

  • Acute genital tract infection (Eg: Genital herpes infection)
  • Viable intrauterine pregnancy
  • During menstruation, as the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high.
  • Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size ≥ 12 weeks form relative contraindications.
  • Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation.
