questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with the diagnosis of mycosis fungoides. Which of the following features is not seen in the histopathological examination in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, civatte bodies are not seen in the histopathological study of mycosis fungoides. They are seen in lichen planus.

Civatte bodies (also known as colloid bodies) are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consisting largely of keratin intermediate filaments and immunoglobulins. 

Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterized by polymorphic patches and plaques with fine scaling usually present on the limbs, breast, and buttocks. The lesions may be pruritic or even asymptomatic.

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane) (Option A).
  • Epidermotropism - pronounced invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis (Option B).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters, forming a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis (Option D).

Image below showing erythematous plaques seen in mycosis fungoides

questions.text: An elderly female patient with a history of severe vomiting was treated aggressively for severe dehydration at an outside hospital. One week later, she became mute, quadriplegic, and rigid. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Severe/ intractable vomiting is a common cause of hyponatremia. The development of quadriplegia, mutism, and rigidity after treatment is suggestive of rapid correction of hyponatremia, leading to central pontine myelinolysis (CPM). It is a complication associated with the treatment of hyponatremia and can present a few days after the initial correction, as seen in this patient.

Rapid correction of hyponatremia (at a rate of >8–10 mM in 24 hours or 18 mM in 48 hours) causes hypertonic stress, leading to apoptosis and cell death. Demyelination without inflammation occurs at the base of the pons with the relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.

CPM, better known now as osmotic demyelination syndrome, commonly involves the pons; but it may also cause extrapontine myelinolysis, affecting the cerebellum, putamen, thalamus, or lateral geniculate bodies. This can result in quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, mutism, ataxia, parkinsonism, and catatonia.

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without paraplegia.

Prevention of CPM depends on therapeutic guidelines for the restoration of severe hyponatremia which should aim for gradual correction i.e. at a rate of ≤10 mmol/L (10 mEq/L) within 24 h and ≤20 mmol/L (20 mEq/L) within 48 h.

The image shows the MRI finding of central pontine myelinolysis with axial fat-saturated T2-weighted MRI showing a hyperintense signal in the central pons.

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia is a condition in which the patient develops sustained muscle contraction and hyperthermia. It occurs following the administration of succinylcholine and other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc.

Option B: Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities such as stupor, mutism, and posturing.

Option D: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening adverse effect of antipsychotics characterized by increased pulse and blood pressure; motor and behavioral symptoms such as muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, and agitation; and autonomic symptoms like hyperthermia. Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatine phosphokinase, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria.

questions.text: Which of the following features would be considered as a contraindication for endoscopic mucosal resection in a patient with early gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulcerated gastric cancer as ulceration indicates advanced disease. 

Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer:

  1. Tumors smaller than 2cm
  2. Tumors limited to the mucosa
  3. No lymphovascular invasion
  4. No ulceration
  5. Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology.

If any of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

FDA has approved the use of Nivolumab in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs, for the initial treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic gastric cancer, GE junction cancer, and esophageal adenocarcinoma. This is the first FDA- approved immunotherapy for the first-line treatment of gastric cancer.

questions.text: A child was weaned off of breastmilk by 3 months of age which caused severe malnutrition and recurrent infections. This falls under which ecological factor of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario showing early curtailment of breastfeeding causing malnutrition is one example of child-rearing practices that leads to malnutrition.

Ecology of Malnutrition :

The ecological factors related to malnutrition as follows 

  1. Conditioning influences: A conditioning factor that plays a huge role in malnutrition is infectious diseases which causes a vicious cycle where infections cause malnutrition which in turn causes minor childhood ailments. Diarrhoeal diseases, intestinal parasites, measles, whooping cough, malaria, tuberculosis contributes significantly to malnutrition. The occurrence of infections are largely based on the environmental conditions that the child is exposed to.
  2. Cultural influences: Poor diets as a result of cultural and regional influences also play a role in malnutrition. They are as follows with an example for each:
    • Food habits, traditions, customs, beliefs and attitudes: Rice and wheat are largely staple in India. Papaya is avoided as it is thought to cause abortion.
    • Religion: Hindus do not eat beef and Muslims do not eat pork.
    • Food fads: Personal likes and dislikes to a certain group of foods.
    • Cooking practices: Prolonged boiling of cereals in open pans which leads to a loss of nutritive value
    • Child-rearing practices: Premature curtailment of breastfeeding
  3. Socio-economic factors: Poverty plays a huge role in causing malnutrition. This is usually a result of ignorance, insufficient education, lack of knowledge regarding the nutritive value of foods, inadequate sanitary environment, large family size, etc. which affects the quality of life.
  4. Food production: The amount of food produced is directly proportional to the amount of food consumed. Developed countries have 5.8 hectares of arable land compared to the 0.6 hectares of land per Indian. Even distribution of food among all sectors of society is also a factor.
  5. Health and other services: Remedial actions that can be taken by the health sector to reduce malnutrition are as follows - 
    • Nutritional surveillance - Continuous monitoring of factors that affect nutrition; groups affected are identified.
    • Nutritional rehabilitation - Urgent care for individuals suffering from severe malnutrition.
    • Nutrition supplementation - Supplementary feeds for mothers and children
    • Health education - Health education programmes to increase awareness about malnutrition and nutrition value of food.

questions.text: A 40 years old man who is a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. His elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40. The ultrasound abdomen is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with a family history of stroke and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males. 

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to haemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Hematuria
  • Uremia
  • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Berry aneurysms (Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%.)
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal hernias
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

 Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Treatment includes

  • Surgical decompression is not a routine procedure performed in these patients. It may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts.
  • Analgesics
  • Increased fluid intake 
    • Prevents renal stone formation
    • Reduces growth of cysts by suppressing ADH release
  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs
    • Blood pressure control 
    • Slowing of cyst growth
  • Tolvaptan (V2 receptor antagonist)
    • Reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function
  • Long-term dialysis
  • Renal transplant
    • Definitive management
    • Pre-transplant nephrectomy may be required in patients with very large polycystic kidneys

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) occurs secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene. The severe form manifests in-utero or during infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life. 

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a relatively rare complication of ADPKD. There does not seem to be an increased frequency of RCC in these patients compared to the general population. However, when it occurs, it tends to be bilateral, multicentric and of sarcomatoid type.

 Tuberculosis kidney presents as putty kidney characterised by amorphous dystrophic calcification.

questions.text: A 65 year male presented with swelling in parotid gland region for 3 months. Which of the following salivary gland neoplasm is responsible for the given appearance in the Tc-99m radionuclide scan?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Warthin's tumor is the salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan as shown in the image.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin's tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Warthins tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a slow-growing, benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor and involves the lower pole of the parotid gland. It usually occurs unilaterally.

Treatment is superficial parotidectomy.

Grossly, they appear as round to oval encapsulated masses, 2-5 cm in diameter, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

The image below shows the gross appearance of Warthin's tumor. Note the well-encapsulated mass.

Histologically, Warthin's tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with a columnar luminal layer and a cuboidal layer. 


Other options:

Only a minority of salivary gland tumors show uptake on 99Tc scintigraphy. They include:

  • Warthins tumor
  • Oncocytoma of salivary glands

Tc-99m radionuclide scan is not done for pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, and adenoid cystic carcinoma as they show variable uptake. 

Option A: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and it most commonly involves the parotid gland (in about 60% of the cases). These are benign and mixed tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. They present in the buccal cavity, parotid, or submandibular area as a painless, slow-growing, mobile mass.

Histopathology:

Grossly, the tumor is rounded and well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in the greatest dimension. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma (image given below).

Microscopic features include the epithelial elements which resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells and these are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells. They are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles are seen in histopathology. The image is shown below.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells resemble swiss cheese due to an organized cribriform growth pattern. The image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following measures would be most useful to prevent pelvic organ prolapse in a patient who has delivered vaginally?
questions.solution:
Kegel's exercises would be most useful in preventing future pelvic organ prolapse.

Kegel pelvic floor exercises involve intermittent tightening of the perineal muscles which leads to strengthening of the pelvic floor muscles especially the pelvic diaphragm (Level III), and decreases the urethral mobility. It is strongly advised for 4-6 months in the puerperal period following vaginal delivery to strengthen the tone of the pelvic diaphragm muscles.

Kegel's exercises or pelvic floor muscle training (PMFT) is useful in the following situations:

  • Before and after delivery to reduce the risk of pelvic organ prolapse and postpartum urinary incontinence.
  • To limit the progression and alleviate symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.
  • As first-line therapy in patients with stress urinary incontinence and urge urinary incontinence.

questions.text: In the labor room, you witness the resident applying dinoprostone gel intracervically to a 38-week primi who is not in labour. Which of the following is an indication for this condition?
questions.solution:
Intracervical dinoprostone gel is applied in order to induce labor, for which abruptio placentae is an indication.

Common indications for induction of labor:

  • Gestational hypertension
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction
  • Intra-uterine death
  • Oligohydramnios

Mechanical methods of induction:

  • Stripping of membranes
  • Artificial rupture of membranes/ surgical induction:  Early amniotomy is associated with a 4-hour reduction in labor duration, however, there is an increased incidence of chorioamnionitis and an unpredictable course.
  • Extraamnionic saline infusion
  • Transcervical bal­loons
  • Hygroscopic cervical dilators

Pharmacological induction of labor:

  • Prostaglandin E2- Dinoprostone gel 0.5mg or dinoprostone insert 10mg
  • Prostaglandin E1- Misoprostol 25mcg vaginally or 50-100mcg orally
  • Oxytocin- 10-20 units in 1000ml ringer lactate

Other options:

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture, only rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is suggestive of pneumonia. Since this patient requires treatment in an ICU setting, the drugs of choice would be ceftriaxone plus azithromycin.

Initial treatment in inpatients with pneumonia:

Non-severe disease

A β-lactam + a macrolide (ceftriaxone + azithromycin)

or

A respiratory fluoroquinolone
Severe disease

 A β-lactam + a macrolide (ceftriaxone + azithromycin)

or 

A β-lactam + respiratory fluoroquinolone

Appropriate antibiotics for Pseudomonas aeruginosa or MRSA are to be added if there is a history of prior isolation from respiratory samples.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough Dry cough
Causes hemoptysis Only scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an Interstitial pattern of involvement.

Remember

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia- Overall, gram-negative bacilli are more commonly implicated as a group; however, the single most common agent is Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: An asthmatic patient was brought to the ER in an agitated state. His respiratory rate was 32/min and pulse was 124/min. Pulse oximetry revealed a SpO2 of 88% on room air. Which of the following drugs is not useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma and cromolyn sodium is not useful in its treatment. It is indicated only for chronic prophylaxis.

Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) and intravenous hydrocortisone are used in the treatment of acute severe asthma.

Ipratropium bromide can also be given in severe asthma exacerbations. It should be given after beta 2-agonists as they have a slower onset of bronchodilatory action.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with cyanosis and dyspnea despite being on high-flow oxygen therapy after using EMLA cream for pain. An ABG reveals a pH of 7.45, pO2 of 100 mmHg, pCO2 of 35 mmHg, and HCO3- of 24 mEq/L. What is the best method of determining oxygen saturation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Co-oximetry is the most accurate method of determining oxygen saturation in patients with methemoglobinemia. It is a spectrophotometer that can measure the relative absorbance of 4 different wavelengths of light, which allows it to differentiate between methemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin, and carboxyhemoglobin. 

This patient likely has methemoglobinemia, as suggested by lack of improvement with oxygen following a history of EMLA cream usage. EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia associated with isosorbide toxicity involves supportive care, cessation of offedning agent, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Pulse oximetry is inaccurate in the setting of methemoglobinemia because it cannot distinguish methemoglobin from oxyhemoglobin. (Option A) Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and irrespective of the methemoglobin levels

Arterial blood gas analysis is a more invasive method of measuring oxygen saturation; It is more accurate than pulse oximetry, but less accurate than co-oximetry. Capillary blood gas analysis is even less accurate than arterial blood gas analysis in the setting of methemoglobinemia. (Options C, D)

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with involuntary weight loss of >10% associated with chronic diarrhea for > 30 days. He was diagnosed with wasting syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be responsible for weight loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Wasting syndrome/ generalized wasting is an AIDS-defining condition associated with involuntary weight loss of >10% of body weight, fever and chronic diarrhoea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Lipoatrophy is not responsible for weight loss in this condition.

The majority of the weight loss in this condition is due to a loss of muscle mass, also known as lean body mass or body cell mass. Bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) or a full body x-ray (DEXA) scan is used to measure it.

A constant feature of this syndrome is severe muscle wasting with scattered myofiber degeneration and occasional evidence of myositis.

Glucocorticoids may be of some benefit. Androgenic steroids, growth hormone, and total parenteral nutrition have all been used as therapeutic interventions, with varying degrees of success.

Wasting syndrome is rarely seen nowadays due to the early initiation of antiretroviral drugs.

HIV-associated lipodystrophy is a side effect of antiretroviral therapy (ART) that occurs due to the redistribution of adipose tissue. It can manifest as fat accumulation (lipohypertrophy) or fat loss (lipoatrophy).

Lipoatrophy is characterised by subcutaneous fat loss in the face, arms, legs, abdomen, and/or buttocks. There is preferential fat loss with no evidence of muscle atrophy, which distinguishes it from AIDS-related wasting syndrome.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea, and fatigue 12 months post childbirth. She has dry skin and hair and decreased libido. Her MRI is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea and fatigue 12 months after childbirth with MRI showing pituitary necrosis, likely has Sheehan syndrome (Ischemic pituitary necrosis). The most appropriate treatment for this patient is hormone replacement therapy; 

The goal of management in Sheehan syndrome is to replace the deficient pituitary hormones. This is typically done with a combination of hydrocortisone, levothyroxine, and oxytocin. Sheehan syndrome is due to pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss after child birth.

The pituitary undergoes hyperplastic enlargement during pregnancy, which increases the risk of haemorrhage and infarction.

The most prominent symptoms are the inability to nurse (lactational failure) due to absent prolactin secretion and postpartum amenorrhea due to absent FSH and LH secretion.

Patients affected may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoglycemia due to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, and hyponatremia. Aldosterone is unaffected, and there is no salt wasting. Adrenal insufficiency is the most life-threatening complication. Hence, the first hormone to be replaced is glucocorticoids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

Option C: Bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor analogue used for the management of lactorrhea seen in a functional prolactinoma. 

Option D: Pituitary resection is appropriate for craniopharyngiomas, benign tumours derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). Patients present with features of raised intracranial pressure, visual impairment in the form of bitemporal hemianopia and endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, diabetes insipidus, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypo-function. MRI shows calcified cystic masses in the supra-sellar region.

questions.text: A 62-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with dizziness and palpitations. On examination, his pulse rate is 132 per minute with an irregularly irregular rhythm. His ECG is given below. He does not have a history of diabetes milletus, congestive heart failure, cerebrovascular or other vascular diseases. What is his CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
The CHA2DS2-VASc score for the described patient is 1. The given clinical scenario and ECG features depict atrial fibrillation. 

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation is recommended if the score is ≥2. The following risk factors are considered during the calculation of the score:

Risk factors Score
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age ≥75years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke or Transient ischemic attack or embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-75years 1
Sex- female 1 

The patient is a known case of hypertension with none of the above-mentioned features present. Hence, his CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors include underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, obesity, and sleeping disorders.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place. Typically, ECG shows an absent P wave.

Management is mainly by control of rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifiable risk factors.

Immediate cardioversion should be done when the patient presents within 48 hours and are at low risk for developing stroke whereas in patients presenting after 48 hours or if the duration is not known, there is an increased risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation should be done for 3 weeks followed by cardioversion and 4 weeks post cardioversion. 

The other approach is to start anticoagulation following transesophageal echo. Cardioversion can be done only if the thrombus is absent. The rate control strategy is achieved with calcium channel blockers/ beta blockers and digoxin.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

Components

Points

C – Congestive heart failure

1

H - Hypertension

1

A – Age > 75 years

2

D – Diabetes Mellitus

1

S – Stroke/TIA/TE

2

VASc-Vascular disease (prior MI, Peripheral Arterial Disease,

or aortic plaque)

  1
 A- Age 65–74 years  1
 S- sex category (i.e., female sex)  1

 

CHADS2 score

Antithrombotics

0

Aspirin or no antithrombotics

1

Aspirin or oral anticoagulant

>1

Oral anticoagulant

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was incidentally diagnosed with a non-functional adrenal tumor of size 3 cm during his routine check-up. Subsequently, in about 3 months, the size of the tumor in MRI increases by about 40%. The next ideal step in the treatment of this patient would be:

choices.text: CT-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the tumor

questions.solution:
From the given description, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the ideal and definitive management in non-functional adrenal tumors, i.e, incidentalomas more than 4 cm in size. An increase in the size of the tumor by 40% indicates an increase in size by 1.2 cm. Thus, the total size of the tumor here is 4.2 cm. 

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies. The majority of these lesions are non-functional.  Secondary metastasis from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients. Functional tumors may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc. These tumors can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm. 

Management of non-functional incidentalomas < 4cm is conservative with routine MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If > 4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

 Other options - 

A. Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. Observation is not a followed protocol unless they're not functional or benign. 

B. Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is avoided as it is inconclusive to distinguish adrenal adenomas from carcinomas. It can be considered in suspected extra-adrenal secondary metastasis. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before the procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

C. Follow-up MRI with 3-6 months surveillance is done for non-functional tumors <4cm size.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient presented with acute renal failure. A dynamic radionuclide renography was ordered to assess the renal perfusion. Which of the following radionuclides are preferred?

99mTc-MAG3 - mercaptoacetyltriglycine 

99m-Tc-MDP - methylene diphosphonate
questions.solution:
99mTc-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for performing dynamic radionuclide renography, to assess renal perfusion.

99mTc-MAG3 dynamic radionuclide renography is the simplest and safest way to assess renal perfusion in patients with renal failure. It helps in differentiating the reversible causes of acute renal failure such as acute tubular necrosis, from conditions like intrinsic parenchymal disease where it is severely impaired or absent.

Dynamic renography:

  • Used to assess split renal function and drainage from the renal collecting systems in suspected obstruction.
  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function.
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR.

Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 Dynamic Renography:

  • To find divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated.
  • To find differential renal function following surgery or procedure. Examples: post pyeloplasty or post removal of a double J stent.
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction, following renal transplantation.

Other options:

Option A- 99mTc-pertechnetate is used in imaging of thyroid, salivary glands, and Meckel's diverticulum imaging.

Option B- 99mTc-sulphur colloid is used in liver/spleen imaging, and prosthetic infection.

Option D- 99m-Tc-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is used for bone scintigraphy.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease.

It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in α-L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis.

Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, and shallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiac complications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death. 

The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges. 

Other options:

Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associated with an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal cortical carcinoma.

Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal and mesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present with hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions, thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles.

Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, short extremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broad protruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin. 

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the management steps in a case of variceal bleeding
  1. Resuscitation and IV Terlipressin/ Octreotide
  2. TIPSS
  3. Balloon tamponade
  4. Endoscopic banding
  5. Shunt surgery
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in the management of variceal bleeding is Resuscitation and IV Terlipressin/ Octreotide -> Endoscopic banding -> Balloon tamponade -> TIPSS -> Shunt surgery.

 Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K, and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

TIPSS or Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Stent Shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

questions.text: On a CT scan, intracranial calcifications seen in all of the following structures are considered normal in the elderly population, except ___________.
questions.solution:
The red nucleus is not a usual site of normal intracranial calcification.

Sites of normal intracranial calcification, visible on CT scan are:

  • Pineal
  • Habenula
  • Choroid plexuses
  • Dura (falx; tentorium; over vault)
  • Ligaments (petroclinoid and interclinoid)
  • Pacchionian bodies
  • Basal ganglia and dentate nuclei
  • Pituitary gland

questions.text: A patient was taken up for surgery and was administered an inhalational agent for anesthesia. Suddenly his heart rate dropped from 94/min to 58/min. Which anesthetic agent was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
Halothane induces bradycardia and causes the maximum reduction in cardiac output, as it blunts the baroreceptor reflex and depresses myocardial contractility.

Normally, hypotension inhibits baroreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid sinus, causing a decrease in vagal stimulation and a compensatory rise in heart rate.

Halothane and enflurane produce a greater decrease in myocardial contractility than isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane which preserve the baroreceptor reflexes and produce tachycardia in response to a fall in arterial pressure.

Cardiac output is best preserved with isoflurane. Though it produces some myocardial depression, reflex tachycardia maintains cardiac output, isoflurane is the agent of choice in cardiac patients.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent     

 Nitrous oxide>Desflurane 

Most epileptogenic  

 Enflurane

Most nephrotoxic  

 Methoxyflurane 

Most hepatotoxic 

 Halothane 

 

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: Identify the hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus.
questions.solution:
Growth hormone, despite being present at higher levels in the fetus, does not play a significant role in fetal growth.

The human fetus produces thyroxine from the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine and insulin have an important role in regulating tissue growth and differentiation of the fetus, particularly during late gestation. Glucocorticoids play an important role towards the end of gestation in the prepartum maturation of organs such as the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract. 

Insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-1 and IGF-II also play an important role in fetal growth.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who is a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. Angiography showed an anterior communicating artery (ACA) aneurysm. The ultrasound abdomen is shown below. What is the best management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with an aneurysm and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The best management would be tolvaptan and long-term dialysis.

Management of ADPKD includes non-pharmacological methods by increasing fluid intake to prevent renal stone formation and to reduce the growth of cyst by depressing ADH release.

Pharmacological methods include using analgesics, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs to control blood pressure and slow the cyst growth, and tolvaptan(V2 receptor antagonist) to reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function.

Surgical decompression may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts. If nephron-sparing surgery isn't possible, nephrectomy is indicated.

More than half of the patients require long-term peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis or kidney transplant.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for estrogen therapy?
questions.solution:
Uterine fibroid is a contraindication for estrogen therapy as the fibroids may enlarge in size with estrogen therapy.

Contraindications for estrogen therapy:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of a thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

 Hypertension, diabetes, and smoking are not contraindications, provided they are regularly monitored.

questions.text: A 80-year-old man with a known history of varicose veins, presents with an ulcer over the gaiter zone of his leg. The intern is instructed to start the patient on Bisgaard’s regimen. Which of the following is not a component of this regimen?

choices.text: Elevation of limb to reduce edema
Early use of pentoxifylline to improve circulation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an ulcer over the gaiter zone developing in a patient with a history of varicose veins is suggestive of a venous ulcer. Pentoxifylline to improve circulation is not a component of Bisgaard’s regimen.

Venous ulcers are due to chronic venous insufficiency and are particularly seen in the lower ⅓ of the leg above the ankle on the medial aspect, known as the gaiter zone. Ambulatory venous hypertension is the most acceptable theory in the pathophysiology of venous ulcers. Venous ulcers have a sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by slough and exudate. Marjolin’s ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma seen in chronic long-standing venous ulcers.

 

Management of venous ulcers:

  • Bisgaard's regimen (4Es)
    • Education of the patient
    • Elevation of the affected limb to reduce the edema
    • Elastic compression stockings - The ideal interface pressure in venous ulceration is 35-40 mmHg.
    • Evaluation
  • 4-layer bandaging system comprising of:
    • Orthopedic wool
    • Cotton crepe
    • Elastic bandage - first compressive layer
    • Cohesive bandage - second compressive layer
  • Antibiotics are given only if the wound is infected.
  • Regular dressing.
  • Medical management by oral pentoxifylline is considered which helps in reducing the viscosity and improving circulation. 
  • Surgical management by ulcer excision with pinch mesh grafting has a good outcome and helps in preventing recurrence.

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a negative pressure dressing. An occlusive dressing is placed over the sore and it is connected to VAC that generates -125mmHg of pressure. It is used in chronic non-healing ulcers, venous ulcers, diabetic ulcers, burn wounds, and bed sores.

questions.text: A neonatologist advises the family of a newborn weighing 1.9 kg to practice the following method. What is incorrect about the baby's positioning in this method?

choices.text: Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position.
The abdomen should be at the level of mother's epigastrium.
The legs should be extended and adducted.

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care (KMC), and the baby's legs must be flexed and abducted, not extended and adducted.

The Kangaroo positioning:

  • Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position. It keeps the airway of the baby open and allows eye-to-eye contact with the mother. 
  • The abdomen should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. The mother's breathing stimulates the baby, thus preventing apnea. 
  • The arms should be flexed.
  • The legs should be flexed and abducted in a 'Frog' position. 

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

KMC can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC can even be done on mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behaviour. This is an example of _______ approach towards health education.
questions.solution:
The No Smoking sign is an example of regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behaviour.

Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment. Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve personal choices like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behavior laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhea

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a violaceous growth on the hard palate in an HIV patient is diagnostic of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease. 

AIDS-associated KS is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. Involvement of the oral cavity is most common in AIDS-related KS, but it can be seen in other variants also. Oral KS (OKS) most often involves the hard and soft palate, gingiva, and dorsal tongue with plaques or tumors. The color of the lesions may range from non-pigmented to brownish-red or violaceous.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

There is no definitive cure but KS is highly radiosensitive and achieves complete response in most cases. In AIDS‐associated KS, instituting highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) often (but not always) results in regression of KS. In localized cutaneous KS, excision and cryotherapy can be used. Intra-lesional administration of vinblastine, interferon‐α2b, and imiquimod is also effective.

Other options:

Option A: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) most commonly tends to occur in sun-exposed areas of the face like the nose, eyelid, and other parts of the face. BCC can vary from red, flesh-colored, or white macules or papules, to nodules and ulcerated lesions. The nodular variant is the most common subtype characterized by raised, pearly pink papules with telangiectasias and occasionally a depressed tumor center with raised borders giving the classic “rodent ulcer” appearance.

The image below shows a case of basal cell carcinoma.

Option C: Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction but may also originate from mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx, nasopharynx, eyes, proximal esophagus, anorectal, and female genitalia. Lentigo maligna, superficial spreading, acral lentiginous, and nodular are the variants of malignant melanoma. It includes pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Amelanotic lesions appear as raised pink, purple, or flesh-colored skin papules. The diagnostic clue for melanoma is the ABCDE criteria.

 

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer. UV radiation exposure is the primary risk factor for SCC. Classically, it appears as a scaly or ulcerated papule or plaque that can bleed with minimal trauma, but the pain is rare. It can exhibit in situ (confined to the epidermis) or invasive subtypes. Wide surgical excision including subcutaneous fat is the treatment of choice for SCC.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is being evaluated for epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few weeks. He also gives a history of occasional black discoloration of the stools. A barium study was done for the patient. Which of the following findings on barium study would indicate that the ulcer is benign?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric ulcers and the presence of Hampton's lines on barium study would indicate that the gastric ulcer is benign.

Hampton's line is a thin radiolucent line seen at the base of a gastric ulcer in barium studies. It represents the preserved gastric mucosa with undermining of the more vulnerable submucosa. It indicates the benign nature of the gastric ulcer.

Other features of a benign ulcer include:

  • The smooth rim of lucency at the base of the ulcer.
  • Converging folds
  • Round, linear, or oval-shaped ulcer
  • Symmetrical, gently sloping ulcer mass.

Difference between benign and malignant gastric ulcer:

Barium swallow findings Benign Malignant
Hampton’s line Present Absent
Extends beyond the gastric wall Yes No
Folds Smooth, even Irregular, nodular, may fuse
Carman meniscus Absent Present
Ulcer shape Round, oval, linear Irregular

Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers. It refers to the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer, nodular mound, and thickened, irregular interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer, loss of mucosal pattern, and incomplete healing.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and features of right heart failure. Family history is positive for sudden cardiac death in his brother. His ECG is given below. The marked changes in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The changes marked in ECG show a notched deflection at the end of the QRS complex due to delayed ventricular activation known as an epsilon wave. It is commonly seen in patients with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterised by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

The patients usually present with rhythm disturbances, right-sided heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy and hyperkeratosis of the palmar and the plantar surfaces. 

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis. In ARVC, there is T inversion and delayed ventricular activation manifesting as epsilon waves.

Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

Option C: Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia, hypercalcemia, brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, or idiopathic ventricular fibrillation. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.

Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A delivery procedure used in a primigravida is shown below. Which of the following is not a prerequisite for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery, and the presence of intact membranes is not a prerequisite for this procedure.

The prerequisites for operative vaginal delivery (forceps or vacuum application) are as follows:

  • Fetal head engaged (head ≤1/5 palpable per abdomen) (Option B)
  • Cervix fully dilated (Option A)
  • Membranes ruptured
  • Fetal head position exactly known 
  • Pelvis deemed adequate (Option C) 

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery; it facilitates delivery by creating a vacuum between itself and the fetal scalp. During vacuum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point. A flexion point is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanelle or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. The flexion point and, hence, the cup is closer to the posterior fontanelle.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks POG)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

Below is the image of a vacuum extractor. 

Traction should be abandoned if

  • There is no descent of the presenting part with each pull.
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

The traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes under any circumstance. An artificial caput succedaneum-chignon is produced due to the sucking and usually disappears within a few hours. Vacuum delivery has reduced maternal pelvic floor injury, and it is the instrument of the choice in assisted delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors?
questions.solution:
Metazoonoses are a type of zoonoses where the infective agents are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. They multiply and develop within the invertebrates (extrinsic incubation period) before transmission to a vertebrate host.

A zoonosis is any disease or infection that is naturally transmissible from vertebrate animals to humans. They can be classified based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses - transmitted from lower vertebrates to man
  • Zooanthroponoses - transmitted from man to lower vertebrates 
  • Amphixenoses - may be transmitted in either direction

They can also be classified based on the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact, fomites, mechanical vector

No developmental or propagative changes during transmission

Rabies, brucellosis, trichinosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

Require > 1 vertebrate host to complete the developmental cycle

Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors 

Infective agent develops and multiplies within the invertebrate (extrinsic incubation period) after which it is transmitted to another vertebrate host

Arboviral infections, plague and schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil, plants) developmental site or reservoir

Various forms of larva migrans and mycoses

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia is posted for laser ablation surgery. Which of the following lasers is commonly used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Holmium YAG laser is commonly used for laser ablative surgery of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which involves electrocautery. Laser ablative techniques use holmium YAG commonly. Laser treatment post-surgery is useful in maintaining the hemostasis of small vessels. KTP laser is used to vaporize prostatic tissue. 

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Recurrent gross hematuria
  • Recurrent bladder stones
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with renal functional impairment

Related Pearl: Lasers used in various specialities

  • Posterior capsulotomy
  • Iridotomy
  • Vitreolysis

Urology

  • Bladder cancer

GIT

  • Fragmentation of gall stones
Holmium YAG

Urology

  • Lithotripsy
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Urethral stricture

 
Carbon dioxide

  • Stapedectomy
  • Tympanomastoid surgery

  • LASIK
