questions.text: An 8-year-old boy had abdominal pain for the past 1 week and associated swelling of his knees with non-blanching rashes. His platelet levels were normal. What is the probable immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a boy presenting with abdominal pain, swelling of knees, non-blanching rashes, and a normal platelet count is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. Vasculitis occurs due to immune complex depositions involving IgA. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. Renal manifestations vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show a mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. IgA and C3 complements are elevated in the serum. 

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

Type I (Anti-GBM Antibody)

Renal limited

Goodpasture syndrome

Immunofluorescence: 

Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3

Type II (Immune Complex)

Idiopathic

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Lupus nephritis

Henoch–Schönlein purpura

IgA nephropathy

Others: Cryoglobulinemia, Bacterial endocarditis, sepsis, acute pancreatitis/advanced liver disease

Immunofluorescence: Granular pattern of staining

Type III (Pauci-Immune)

ANCA-associated

Idiopathic

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescence: No immunoglobulin or complement deposits

 

Image: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (PAS stain) with the crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and leukocytes internal to Bowman capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Malnutrition Universal Screening tool?
questions.solution:
Age is not a criterion used in MUST.

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) is a five-step screening tool to identify malnourished adults or adults at risk of malnutrition.

Related Pearl: Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST)

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool, ‘MUST’ is a five-step screening tool to identify adults, who are malnourished, at risk of malnutrition (undernutrition), or obese. It also includes management guidelines which can be used to develop a care plan.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy presents with repeated epileptic spasms. Lately, his parents noticed that he is no longer able to hold his head steadily. EEG findings are given below. On examination, ash-leaf-like hypopigmented macules on both hands and an irregularly thickened skin-coloured patch on the lower back are seen. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of infantile spasms, developmental regression (inability to hold his head steadily) and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes) are suggestive of West syndrome. The drug of choice for treating this condition is Vigabatrin.

The presence of ash leaf-like hypopigmented macules and an irregularly thickened skin-coloured patch on the lower back (Shagreen patch) also suggests the child has Tuberous Sclerosis. 

The drug of choice for treating this condition is Vigabatrin. Vigabatrin is a GABA uptake inhibitor that has been found to be effective in controlling infantile spasms associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. 

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and is characterized by salaam spells (sudden dropping of the head or flexion of arms, followed by tonic extension of arms and legs) and hypsarrhythmia on EEG.

The image given below illustrates infantile spasms in a child:

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is considered to be the drug of choice for infantile spasms. It acts by (1) inducing steroid release and (2) a direct, steroid-independent action on melanocortin receptors. 

Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or the TSC2 gene. The clinical features seen are as follows: 

  • Seizures
  • Intellectual disability
  • White ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs.
  • Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas)
  • Shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin‐coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
  • Periungual fibromas
  • Renal angiomyolipomas

Diagnostic Criteria for Tuberous Sclerosis- 

Major Criteria Minor Criteria
Hypomelanotic macules (≥3; at least 5mm diameter) “Confetti” skin lesions
Angiofibroma (≥3) or fibrous cephalic plaque Dental enamel pits (≥3)
Ungual fibromas (≥2) Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
Shagreen patch Retinal achromic patch
Multiple retinal hamartomas Multiple renal cysts
Subependymal nodule (≥2) Nonrenal hamartomas
Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma Sclerotic bone lesions
Cardiac rhabdomyoma  
Lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM)  
Angiomyolipomas (≥2)  


Definite TSC: either two major features or one major feature with two minor features.

Other options:

Valproate and Phenytoin act by blocking both calcium and sodium channels and are 1st line drugs used in the treatment of Generalised Tonic Clonic seizures. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray was done as shown below. Which of the following types of this condition causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the X-ray showing a snowman appearance of the heart is suggestive of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC). The infracardiac type causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction.

In the infracardiac variety of TAPVC, the common pulmonary vein drains to the portal vein instead of joining the left atrium. The pulmonary vein gets obstructed as it enters the diaphragm through the esophageal orifice.

TAPVC is a congenital cardiac malformation where pulmonary veins return to the right atrium or systemic venous circulation instead of draining directly to the left atrium.

According to the site of anomalous connection, the TAPVC can be divided into four subtypes:

  1. Supracradiac (Most common)
  2. Cardiac
  3. Infracardiac
  4. Mixed

Percentage of obstruction in different types of TAPVC:

Type of TAPVC  % with significant obstruction 
Infracardiac 95-100
Supracardiac 40-75
Cardiac 5-10
Mixed -

Neonates with severe obstruction to pulmonary venous return (infracardiac group) present with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. Murmurs may be absent on cardiac examination.

Children with mild or no obstruction to pulmonary venous return (supracardiac or cardiac) develops heart failure due to a fall in pulmonary vascular resistance. They are associated with systolic murmurs.

The image given below shows x-ray findings of TAPVC.

A 2D echocardiography and doppler are used for the diagnosis of TAPVC where it fails to demonstrate draining of pulmonary vein to the left atrium. The right atrium and right ventricle are often enlarged. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

TAPVC is treated by emergent surgical correction. If surgery cannot be performed urgently, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may be required to maintain oxygenation.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the method of contraception shown in the image below.

choices.text: It cannot be used in the puerperal period
It is impermeable to cytomegalovirus, hepatitis B and HIV.
Male partner should use a condom to increase the efficacy
Should be fitted and removed only by a medical professional

questions.solution:
The image shows a female condom and it is impermeable to HIV, Hepatitis B, and cytomegalovirus.

The female condom, also known as femidom or femshield is a pre-lubricated polyurethane cylindrical sheath with a flexible ring at both ends. The outer open ring remains outside the vagina and the inner closed ring is fitted beneath the cervix. 

 

 

It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm.

The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they may slip, tear, or become displaced.

Other barrier methods of contraception include:

  • Male condom
  • Cervical cap
  • Cervical diaphragm - used with or without a spermicidal agent
  • Vaginal sponge

questions.text: A heavy weight lifter complains of low backache for 3 months. On examination there is asymmetric motor and sensory loss in the lower limbs with absent knee and ankle jerks. Bowel and bladder functions are normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is cauda equina syndrome. 

Cauda equina syndrome refers to an injury to the lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal, occurring distal to the termination of spinal cord at L1-L2 level. It occurs most commonly due to rupture of lumbosacral intervertebral disc. Other causes include lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within spinal canal, and compressive mass lesions such as tumors.

The patients present with low back ache (most often a radicular type of pain), lower limb weakness and sensory loss, and areflexia in the lower limbs. Bowel and bladder functions are preserved. Treatment is with urgent surgical decompression of the involved area.

Other options :

Option A: Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to gray matter cells and spinothalamic tracts, which are present in the vicinity of the central canal. It occurs due to syringomyelia (cervical cord involvement), spinal trauma and intrinsic tumors of the spinal cord. Patients with cervical cord involvement present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option B: Patients with Brown-Séquard syndrome present with:

  • Ipsilateral weakness due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense due to the involvement of the posterior column tracts.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.

Option D: Patients with conus medullaris syndrome present with bilateral saddle anesthesia, prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction, and impotence. While knee jerk is often preserved, they have a loss of bulbocavernosus and anal reflexes.

questions.text: A sexually active young woman presents with abdominal pain in her left lower abdomen. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago and she has regular monthly menstrual cycles. Vitals are normal. What could be the cause of the pain?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain 2 weeks after her last menstrual cycle with stable vitals most likely has pain due to Mittelschmerz syndrome. Follicular rupture is the cause of mittelschmerz.

Mittelschmerz, or ovulation pain, is a mid-cycle ache that is usually intense but can sometimes occasionally be mild for several hours. It usually occurs during the LH peak and is caused by the rupture of a Graffian follicle.

It occurs due to the contractions of the ovarian perifollicular smooth muscles which is mediated through PGF2a. Treatment is with NSAIDs.

Other options : 

Option A: PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge associated with cervical motion tenderness.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancies usually rupture after 4-6 weeks of gestation and patients may have hypotension due to bleeding into the abdominal cavity. This patient has stable vitals. 

Option D: Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammation of the fallopian tube, marked by nodular thickening in its isthmic segment. This thickening results from the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula in the tubal epithelium. It commonly affects both fallopian tubes and increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to the nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to the nitrogen intake.

NPU = (Biological value of a food substance x Digestability coefficient) / 100

Note: The NPU of Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia?
questions.solution:
Lewy body dementia causes irreversible dementia.

Dementia is an acquired deterioration in cognitive abilities that impairs the successful performance of activities of daily living. The most commonly lost cognitive function is episodic memory, that is, the ability to recall events specific in time and place.

Causes of dementia are:

Reversible 

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Thiamine deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Normal pressure hydrocephalus
  • Subdural hematoma
  • Brain tumor
  • Chronic infection
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy

Irreversible 

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Vascular dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
  • Frontotemporal dementia
  • Parkinson's disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient comes with chronic right shoulder pain. While examining the patient, the following test elicits weakness in the right shoulder. Which of the following muscles/tendons is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the image is the empty can test and the muscle/tendon implicated here is the supraspinatus.

In this test, the patient is asked to resist the downward force by the examiner, when the arms are in the position of 90° abduction, 30° flexion, and complete internal rotation(as if emptying a can, hence the name of the test). The result is positive if the affected side is weaker than the normal side and indicates a tear in the supraspinatus tendon.

Other options:

Option B: Infraspinatus – Resisted external rotation - The patient flexes elbows to 90 degrees and stands holding his/her arm close to the body. The patient then externally rotates both arms while the examiner applies resistance; lack of power on one side signifies weakness of infraspinatus. 

Option C: Teres minor cannot be assessed separately. But it can assessed along with infraspinatus as they both perform external rotation of the shoulder joint. ‘Lag sign’ and the ‘Drop sign’ are used for this purpose.

The lag sign is performed by asking the patient to lift his arms slightly away from the body and place them in maximum external rotation. A positive test is elicited when the patient cannot maintain that position on one side and allows the arm to drift into a more neutral position. This suggests a tear of the infraspinatus, teres minor, or supraspinatus. 

The drop sign is similar, here the arm is in 90 degrees of abduction, the elbow flexed to 90 degrees and the arm maximally externally rotated. When the examiner lets go, the patient would normally hold that position, but if the arm ‘drops’, it denotes a positive test

Option D: Subscapularis –Lift-off test - The patient places one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The patient’s hand is lifted off the back and the patient is told to hold it there. The inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came to the dermatology department with the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given image and the clinical history, the diagnosis is Berloque dermatitis.

Berloque dermatitis is a type of skin pigmentation due to an acute phototoxic reaction to perfumes applied to the skin.

Berloque dermatitis results from the potentiation of UV-stimulated melanogenesis by 5-methoxypsoralen (bergapten) in perfumes containing bergamot oil.

Deep-brown pigmentation follows the pattern formed by the trickle of the droplets of perfume over the skin from their points of application.

Treatment:

1) Avoidance of perfumes

2) Oral antihistamines

3) Parenterally administered epinephrine in case of anaphylactic reactions

Other options:

Option A: Post-inflammatory hypermelanosis: It is residual macular pigmentation resulting from prior skin inflammation.

Option B : Phytophotodermatitis: It is an inflammatory and pigmentary reaction of the skin to light, potentiated by furocoumarins in plants.

Option D: Drug-induced hyperpigmentation: It is localised or generalised hyperpigmentation caused by a wide range of medications or chemicals such as,

  • Amiodarone
  • Antimalarial drugs
  • Clofazimine
  • Busulfan
  • Hydantoin
  • Trifluoperazine
  • Tetracycline, etc.,

questions.text: What drug is used to estimate pseudocholinesterase function?
questions.solution:
Dibucaine is a local anaesthetic which measures pseudocholinesterase function but not the amount of enzyme.

It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity. A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80.

Therefore, the adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined:

  • Quantitatively in units per liter - in the laboratory
  • Qualitatively by dibucaine number

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding adequate thyroid FNAC sampling?
questions.solution:
6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells are considered adequate thyroid FNAC sampling.

There are different criteria for the adequacy of thyroid FNAC:

  • Six groups with at least 10 cells in each group, or 
  • Ten groups with at least 20 cells in each group, are considered adequate.

Cystic goitre may not yield thyroid follicular cells, hence, the aspiration should be repeated under USG guidance.

FNAC is the investigation of choice in discrete thyroid swellings; it has excellent patient compliance, simple and quick to perform in the outpatient department and is readily repeated.

Bethesda criteria for reporting thyroid cytopathology:

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with multiple brown coffee coloured  skin rashes. She has increased uptake on bone scans over the femur, skull, and ribs. Biochemical parameters are abnormal. She also has a history of hypothyroidism. An X-ray of her femur is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows the bending of the femur known as Shepherd's crook deformity. It is seen in fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Her symptoms are a part of McCune Albright syndrome. McCune Albright syndrome presents as a triad of cafe-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. It is also associated with multiple endocrinopathies like hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, etc. The locus of involvement is the GNAS1 gene. 

Cutaneous pigmentation is more prominent on the side with severe bone involvement. Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. The presentation often occurs in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

Radiological findings include:
  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy ground glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur.

questions.text: A woman presented with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer.

The ER and PR are two steroid hormone receptors present in breast cancer. The expression of these receptors indicates a favorable prognosis and response to hormonal therapy.

Other options:

Option A: The mutations in BRCA1 gene account for up to 40% of familial breast cancers. These tumors are high-grade, hormone receptor–negative, and aneuploid and do not have a good prognosis.

Option B: p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, which on mutation acts as an oncogene. p53 positivity is associated with highly malignant breast cancers and has poor survival.

Option D: Ki-67 is used to access the proliferative index (activity) of the tumor. High Ki-67 indicates a poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

 

Molecular subtypes 

Receptor status

Histological subtypes

Luminal A type 

(most common, best prognosis)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

<14% (low)

Lobular carcinoma

Mucinous carcinoma

Tubular carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2/neu negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2 

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

>14% (high)

Poorly differentiated, lobular-carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2 positive)

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- +ve

Ki-67- 

variable

  

HER2 enriched

Mutated gene- TP53

ER/PR- -ve

Her2- +ve

Ki-67- 

High 

Apocrine carcinoma

Micro-papillary carcinoma

 

Basal type (Triple-negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 1

ER/PR- -ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67-

Medullary carcinoma

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

ER-positive, HER2- negative

  		  

HER2- Positive (ER- positive or negative)

ER- negative

HER2- negative

Frequency

~40-55% (Low proliferation)

~10% (High proliferation)

~20%

~15%

Included special histologic types

Well or moderately differentiated lobular, tubular, mucinous

Some apocrine

Typical patient groups

Older women, men, cancers detected by mammographic screening

BRCA2 mutation carriers

Young women, BRCA1 mutation carriers, African American and Hispanic women

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who was previously diagnosed with an ovarian fibroma presents with gradually progressive abdominal distension, cough, breathlessness, and pleuritic chest pain on the right side. On examination, the abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is present. Chest x-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the triad of benign ovarian fibroma, right-sided pleural effusion, and ascites are suggestive of Meigs syndrome.

The following triad of features favors the diagnosis:

  • Gradual progressive distension of abdomen, positive fluid thrill – points towards ascites.
  • Cough on lying to the right side, breathlessness, chest pain on the right side, chest X-ray – point towards right-sided pleural effusion.
  • Diagnosis of ovarian fibroma– benign ovarian tumor.

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary (other than fibromas). Other features may include fibroids/leiomyoma, secondary metastatic tumors to the ovary, Brenners tumors, and benign ovarian cysts (such as struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, and teratomas).

Option C: Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

Option D: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. It is characterized by the inflammation of the peritoneum and the tissues surrounding the liver (perihepatitis). Symptoms include sudden onset of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, fever, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A nurse was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, the following was seen. There was no associated skin change or venous ulcer. According to the CEAP classification system, she would be classified as
questions.solution:
According to CEAP classification, Varicose veins without skin changes or ulcer comes under the clinical class of C2.

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes,

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

C2

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C6

*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gout is asked to undergo the radiological test shown below. What is this imaging modality called?
questions.solution:
The above imaging modality is dual-energy CT (DECT).

Dual-energy CT allows for the analysis of energy-dependent variations in the attenuation of various materials by using two distinct X-ray spectra to obtain two image datasets of the same anatomic region. 

It enables material separation to distinguish uric acid crystals from calcium to determine the composition of urinary calculi and diagnose gout.

With the help of a DECT scan, the calcium crystals are coloured blue, while the uric acid crystals are coloured green, making gout diagnosis simple and non-invasive. DECT can also be used to quantify the overall tophus burden or volume of urate deposition without any user variability. This makes DECT an ideal tool for assessing any variation in tophus burden and enables follow-up to record treatment response.

Uses of DECT include:

  • Detection and quantification of urate crystals in gout
  • Characterization of renal stones, cysts and masses 
  • Identification of silicone leaks from breast implants.
  • Detection of bone marrow edema
  • Detection of pulmonary embolism
  • Detection of myocardial ischemia 

Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration, an invasive procedure that could yield false negative results.

Other options

Option B: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agents.

Option C: Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that uses gamma-emitting radioisotopes(tracers) like technetium-99(99mTc) -hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (HMPAO). These radiotracers are used to investigate cerebrovascular diseases and epilepsy. 

The image below shows a SPECT CT depicting hyperactivity of tibial physis in a growing child:


Option D: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following best measures ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), secreted by the granulosa cells, is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the cycle.

AMH is secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testis and granulosa cells in the ovary. In males, it inhibits the development of the Müllerian system and its absence can result in hermaphroditism. In the female, it helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. The estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in an infertile woman and a woman with secondary amenorrhoea. The levels of AMH vary minimally across the cycle and they strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. This makes AMH is the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. AMH levels can be affected by the use of oral contraceptives and tobacco smoking.

Values and interpretation:

  • Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL
  • Poor ovarian reserve : <1 ng/mL
  • PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

Tests for ovarian reserve: Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. The other indicators include:

  • FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle) - High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH (values >25mIU/ml) levels are higher than normal in women with a reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. 
  • Serum oestradiol values on day 3 of the cycle. Serum oestradiol <75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • LH - values <10 IU/L indicates poor reserve
  • Antral follicular count - counts less than 4–5 on days 2–5 denotes poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B - values <40 pg/mL indicates poor reserve

questions.text: A patient who suffered from myocardial infarction four days ago now complains of dyspnea. On auscultation, a pansystolic murmur is heard, which is loudest at the tricuspid area. Which of the following complications is likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient developing pansystolic murmur which is loudest in tricuspid area, four days following a myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of ventricular septal perforation is most likely. 

Pansystolic (or holosystolic) murmurs begin with S1 and continue through systole to S2. They are usually indicative of chronic mitral or tricuspid valve regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Post myocardial infarction ventricular septal rupture produces a pansystolic murmur which is loudest at the mid- to lower-left sternal border and accompanied by a systolic thrill at the left sternal border. This should be differentiated from early systolic murmur, which is seen in acute mitral regurgitation which develops following papillary muscle rupture (option D). This early systolic murmur is best heard at the apical impulse.

Both ventricular septal perforation and papillary muscle rupture mostly occur in the first week following myocardial infarction. A new onset murmur in a patient with myocardial infarction is an indication for transthoracic echocardiography because it allows precise characterization of the pathology behind the murmur. 

Ventricular aneurysm (option A) occurs because of outward bulging of the ventricular wall during contraction (dyskinesia). It is not associated with any mumurs, but it can lead to the formation of mural thrombus and embolism. Ventricular free wall rupture (option B) causes cardiac tamponade and often death.

questions.text:
The barium swallow images of different conditions of the esophagus are given below. Which of the following images represents the condition characterized by the manometric findings given below?
  1. Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  2. Premature spastic contractions.
  3. Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given features is diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)/ Distal esophageal spasm. Image 2 showing a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on a barium swallow represents the condition.

DES is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus that manifests as dysphagia and chest pain that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. It is more common in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Muscular hypertrophy and degeneration of the branches of the vagus nerve in the esophagus are seen in this condition. Oesophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. 

The diagnosis of DES is made by radiographic and manometric studies. Manometric findings are:

  • Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  • Premature spastic contractions.
  • Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.

On barium swallow, a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance is seen. It indicates tertiary contractions and advanced disease.

Treatment is with long-acting nitrates, calcium channel-blocking agents, sedatives, and anticholinergics. Bougie dilation of the esophagus relieves dysphagia in many patients. Intrasphincteric injection of botulinum toxin has been tried. Surgery is indicated for patients who fail to respond to medical or endoscopic therapy.

 
Other options:

Image A: Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis. It affects men more than women. A barium swallow shows the presence of a characteristic bird's beak appearance. It is shown below.

Image C: Feline esophagus refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux. 1-2 mm thick, horizontal folds are seen around the entire circumference following reflux.

Image D: Zenker diverticulum is the most common of all the esophageal diverticula. It is much more commoner in men, after age 60. Patients present with dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. Barium study shows the presence of a diverticulum. It is shown in the image below, indicated by the red arrow.

questions.text: A gastro-surgeon performs a procedure shown below on a young child with Extrahepatic biliary atresia. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image.

It is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilised and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

Other options:

Option B: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

Option C: Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

The following structures are removed during this procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has ideas of grandiosity. He thinks himself to be very successful and correct all the time and cannot tolerate if someone criticises him. What is the type of personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical case scenario is suggestive of narcissistic personality disorder.

 Narcissistic personality disorder is included under cluster B personality disorder.

Cluster B personality disorder / dramatic, emotional, and erratic group:

Patients with these personality disorders characteristically have chaotic lives, emotions, and relationships.

  • Borderline personalities are impulsive, unpredictable, angry, temperamental, unstable in relationships, compulsively interpersonal, and self-damaging with regard to sex, money, and substance use.
  • Histrionic personalities are attention seeking, exhibitionistic, seductive, self-indulgent, exhibit exaggerated expressions of emotions, and overconcerned with physical appearance.
  • Narcissistic personalities tend to be hypersensitive to criticism, exploitative of others, egocentric with an inflated sense of self-importance, feel entitled to special treatment, and demand constant attention.
  • Antisocial personalities are truant, lie, steal, start fights, break rules, are unable to sustain work or school and shirk everyday responsibilities.

 

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: All the following are seen in the clinical condition depicted by the blood picture except _____.
questions.solution:
The above blood picture shows sickle cell anemia. Thrombocytopenia is not seen in sickle cell anemia.

Laboratory findings of sickle cell anemia

  • The peripheral blood smear:
    • Irreversibly sickled cells comprising 5–50% of red cells
    • Reticulocytosis (10–25%)
    • Nucleated red blood cells
    • Howell–Jolly bodies and target cells (Hyposplenism)
  • The white blood cell count - elevated to 12,000–15,000/mcL
  • Reactive thrombocytosis may occur.
  • Indirect bilirubin levels are high.

questions.text: A woman 3 months postpartum who regularly breastfeeds presented with amenorrhea for 3 months and is concerned about this problem and is requesting surgery. Before considering surgery what can be done to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The best management of this patient is to reassure her as this is normal during postpartum and is due to lactactional amenorrhea.

Lactactional amenorrhea:

  • Type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect or prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH and FSH causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided she remains amenorrhoeic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur, despite amenorrhoea and might need other forms of contraception.

Other options:

Oral combined pill in a lactating woman is contraindicated because:

  • It reduces the quality and quantity of milk.
  • The hormone in the milk may be harmful to the infant.
  • Increased risk of thromboembolism.

questions.text: Which is the most common malignant tumour of the minor salivary glands?
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of minor salivary glands.

It is a malignant tumour with a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis.

Surgical removal is often difficult due to invasion into adjacent structures and completely negative margins may not be attainable.

The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, followed by bone, liver and brain.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A  woman presents with a 6-month history of cough, dyspnea, and fatigue. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. She has hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray. Which of the following parameters are likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms, along with hypercalcemia and chest X-ray findings raise suspicion for Sarcoidosis. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are elevated in this condition as sarcoid granulomas secrete it.

Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in Sarcoidosis, Silicosis, Leprosy, Gaucher’s disease, Hyperthyroidism and Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

Two syndromes are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome characterised by bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Chest X-ray findings include:

  • The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.
  • Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.
  • It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE.
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Serum amylase levels are elevated in conditions that affect the pancreas or salivary glands, such as pancreatitis, cancer, sialolithiasis or in the case of Mickulicz syndrome with involvement of the parotid glands.

Option C: Serum calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Serum PTH levels are elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

GRANULOMA SEEN IN
Noncaseating granuloma

Crohn’s disease

Leprosy

Sarcoidosis

Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Caseating granuloma

Tuberculosis

Histoplasmosis

Syphilis

Coccidiomycosis
Foreign body granuloma

Silicosis

Berylliosis
Immune granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis

Giant cell arteritis
Durk’s granuloma Cerebral malaria
Stellate granuloma Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
A thirsty child signifies some dehydration, not severe dehydration. 

Clinical features of severe dehydration in a child include:

  • Drowsy, lethargic or unconscious
  • Drinks poorly or not able to drink
  • Sunken eyes and absent tears
  • Sunken fontanelle
  • Deep breathing
  • Skin pinch goes back very slowly (recoil in >2 seconds)
  • Tachycardia, with bradycardia in most severe cases
  • Weak, thready, or impalpable pulse
  • Prolonged capillary refill
  • Cold, mottled, and cyanotic extremities
  • Minimal urine output 

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: Identify the following test.
questions.solution:
The Patch test is shown in the image which is used to confirm the diagnosis of Allergic contact dermatitis.

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2 and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

 

Option A: Skin prick test involves an intradermal puncture through a drop of allergen placed on the skin.

Positive reaction - an urticarial weal, which is apparent after 15 min - 45 min. 

Below image shows skin prick testing.

 

 

Option C: Casoni's test is an immediate Type I hypersensitivity reaction to hydatid fluid to diagnose Echinococcus granulosus infection.

The antigen extracted from the hydatid fluid is sterilised and injected intradermally in one arm. An equal amount of saline is injected in the other arm as control.

Positive reaction - a wheal of about 5cm with multiple pseudopodia-like projection appears within 30mins and disappears in an hour. A secondary reaction of edema and induration appears after 8 hours.

The image given below shows an intradermal injection as done in casoni's test.

 

Option D: Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) is a blood test used for estimation of specific IgE.

questions.text: Hereditary pheochromocytomas are commonly associated with all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Hereditary pheochromocytomas are not associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type-1.

Hereditary pheochromocytomas occur in several tumour syndromes:

  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2): an autosomal dominant inherited disorder that is caused by activating germline mutations of the RET proto-oncogene.
  • Familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome: glomus tumours of the carotid body and extra-adrenal paraganglioma are characteristic in this hereditary tumour syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations within the succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB) SDHD and SDHC genes.
  • von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome: those affected can develop early-onset bilateral kidney tumours, pheochromocytomas, cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas and pancreatic tumours. Patients have a germline mutation in the VHL gene.
  • Neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1: pheochromocytomas in combination with fibromas on the skin and mucosae (‘café-au-lait’ skin spots) are indicative of a germline mutation in the NF1 gene.

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A child with disruptive behaviour is diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. As the child grows which of his following symptoms is first to remit?
questions.solution:
During the course of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), overactivity is the first symptom to remit, i.e., become less severe.

The course of ADHD is variable. A vast majority of cases persist into adult life. In the cases that remit at puberty or in early adulthood, overactivity is usually the first symptom to remit but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems persist.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.solution:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A type 2 diabetic patient who was recently started on treatment complains of frequent urination, fever, and burning micturition. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use.

The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose. 

  • UTI - due to glucosuria
  • Dehydration - due to natriuresis and volume loss
  • Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis - low blood glucose levels due to glucosuria can reduce insulin release

SGLT-2 inhibitors must be temporarily discontinued for 3-4 days before any scheduled surgery to avoid potential risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.

The FDA recently approved dapagliflozin oral tablets to reduce the risk of renal and cardiac failure in adults with chronic kidney disease who are at risk of disease progression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, and fatigue for the past several months. She has a history of scleroderma diagnosed 10 years ago. Examination reveals right ventricular heave and a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. CXR is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's chest pain?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Scleroderma-associated pulmonary hypertension. In PH, there is an intimal thickening of the pulmonary arteries, which leads to narrowing of the arteries and increased resistance to blood flow: leading to chest pain, dyspnea on exertion and when severe, hemoptysis.

Right ventricular dysfunction occurs with the progression of the disease -syncope, abdominal distention, ascites, and peripheral oedema.
Pulmonary vasculature may have intimal proliferation, fibrosis, and in situ thrombosis. There may be vascular remodelling at late stages. These changes increase right ventricular afterload and total pulmonary vascular resistance. This eventually leads to a drop in cardiac output. It is irreversible and does not have a curative treatment. It can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and right heart catheterization can confirm the diagnosis.

  • Mean pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) > 22 mmHg
  • Estimated systolic PAP > 36 mmHg
  • Pulmonary vascular resistance of ≥3 wood units.

An echocardiogram with a bubble study is an important screening test that will reveal a dilated and hypertrophied right ventricle. On chest x-ray, 'vascular pruning' (as seen in the given CXR) may be seen as well as enlarged pulmonary arteries.

Management for pulmonary hypertension:

Vasoreactivity testing involves the administration of inhaled nitric oxide, IV epoprostenol, IV adenosine, or inhaled iloprost. The test is considered positive if the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAH) decreases by ≥ 10 mmHg leading to mPAH ≤ 40 mmHg, without a decrease in cardiac output (CO).

Positive vasoreactivity test: Calcium channel blockers are indicated. Long-acting nifedipine, diltiazem or amlodipine are used.


Negative vasoreactivity test:

  • For patients with lower risk (class II, III) based on clinical assessment: Oral therapy with endothelin receptor antagonists like ambrisentan, sitaxsentan, bosentan, or phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors (PDE-5 I's) like sildenafil, tadalafil is the first line of therapy.
  • For patients with higher risk (class IV) based on clinical assessment: Continuous treatment with iv prostacyclins (epoprostenol or treprostinil) would be the first line of therapy recommended.
  • Lung transplantation and/or atrial septostomy are reserved for patients who progress despite optimal medical treatment.


Revised WHO classification of pulmonary hypertension:

  • Group I: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • Group II: Pulmonary hypertension with left heart disease
  • Group III: Pulmonary hypertension associated with lung diseases and/or hypoxemia
  • Group IV: Pulmonary hypertension due to chronic thrombotic and/or embolic disease (CTEPH)
  • Group V: Pulmonary hypertension due to miscellaneous causes

Other options:

Option A: Left heart failure would likely be accompanied by orthopnea/PND, S3, or signs of pulmonary oedema on physical exam or chest x-ray.

Option C: Asthma/Anaphylaxis is associated with widespread bronchospasm and is likely to be episodic or associated with an exposure. On examination, wheezing would be seen and CXR would be clear.

Option D: Emphysema is associated with air trapping and alveolar destruction. PAH associated with SSc is more likely in this patient with no smoking history and signs of pruning. Hyper-expansion and diaphragm flattening would be expected on CXR.
